summary: Paul Merson reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend after criticizing Townsend's late substitution in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously questioned Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, which Townsend refuted by scoring a crucial equalizer for England against Italy. Despite admitting his mistake, Merson continued to express his opinion on Townsend's performance and suitability for the England team, prompting another response from Townsend on Twitter.

Chelsea has made an offer for 22-year-old Japanese forward Yoshinori Muto from FC Tokyo, according to club president Naoki Ogane. If the transfer is completed, Muto will join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan for the next season. Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has 11 international caps for Japan and scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo. A £4 million deal is speculated, but Muto has not yet decided if he will join Chelsea. The interest in Muto is not related to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The Finnish researchers compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds with records on antibiotic prescriptions. They found that children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight, with boys being more prone to weight gain. The study suggests that antibiotics may contribute to the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic by killing gut bacteria that would normally consume some of the food eaten, thereby freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The researchers emphasize the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident, which was caught on camera by tourist David Meadwell, left the guard embarrassed as he quickly regained his footing and continued with the ceremony. The guard's fall was attributed to the metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a popular event at Buckingham Palace, attracting thousands of tourists daily.

The epic miniseries "Roots," originally aired in 1977 with over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks for 2016. The new version will be simulcast across A&E, Lifetime, and History. It tells the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery in Virginia. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The new series aims to be "original" and "contemporary," drawing more from Alex Haley's novel "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." Scholars in African and African-American history will be consulted for authenticity. The remake seeks to engage both fans of the original and a new generation, considering recent historical and social contexts such as Barack Obama's presidency and ongoing racial issues in the U.S.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler that palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy in January 1978 at Clarence House, the Queen Mother’s London residence. Lawler, who was 27 at the time, said he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member on his first day working there. He left the job the same day and was reportedly threatened to keep quiet. Lawler contacted palace officials again last year amid inquiries into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s. His complaints were initially ignored but were later passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide reportedly denied involvement as he was working for the Queen in Balmoral at the time. The Royal Household has stated it will work "exhaustively and co-operatively" with any police investigation.

Jesse and Melissa Meek, an Oregon couple, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,' which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. The video, featuring the couple rapping while driving, details their journey to parenthood and includes a sonogram reveal. The couple expressed surprise at the video's viral success and mentioned that it was created to share the news with distant loved ones.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray but faded to light gray, was worn in key scenes, including when Scarlett encounters Rhett Butler and gets attacked in the shanty town. The dress was part of a private collection of over 150 items from the film, amassed by James Tumblin, who bought the dress for $20 before it was to be discarded. Other notable items sold included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, and a suit worn by Clark Gable for $55,000. The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary last year.

A two-year-old boy is recovering from minor bumps and bruises after falling into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo. His mother was holding him and another child when he slipped and fell approximately 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The boy was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. The cheetahs did not approach the boy, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which had been turned off for two years, was re-angled to point directly at a house's front door. The camera, part of around 300 across the West Midlands that were switched off in March 2013 due to obsolete technology, is not included in a new pilot program using digital technology. Birmingham City Council is aware of the issue and will take appropriate action, potentially removing the camera. The owners of the house were not available for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt expressed his happiness to be part of the team and stated that he is fit, healthy, and ready to run. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) General Secretary, Garth Gayle, expressed pleasure at Bolt's participation and anticipated "sprint magic" from him. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves demonstrated their dedication to Barcelona by attending a Euro League basketball match, where Barcelona narrowly defeated Real Madrid 85-80. Neymar, who recently led Brazil to a 1-0 win over Chile, was accompanied by his sister Rafaella. Despite the victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their Euro League division by points difference. Before the international break, Barcelona had also won their El Clasico in La Liga, extending their lead to four points. Neymar and his team-mates are set to return to La Liga action against Celta Vigo as they aim for a treble of trophies.

Italy is facing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with 8,480 migrants rescued from Friday to Monday. Save the Children reported that 400 migrants might be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. Italy has seen over 10,000 migrants arrive in the first three months of 2015, with most coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, transiting through Libya. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year due to bad weather and unsafe vessels.

Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, a decision that Arsene Wenger is pleased with. Sanchez made an immediate impact in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger acknowledges that while he does not know the exact reason for Sanchez's choice, he believes Sanchez's quick adaptation and high work-rate make him one of the best players. Wenger also comments on Liverpool's potential use of their interest in Sanchez as leverage during negotiations for Luis Suarez. Additionally, Wenger downplays speculation about a potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, plans to bid for cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km is held by Australian rider Rohan Dennis, set in February. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career at the Paris-Roubaix race, aims to motivate people by challenging himself and encouraging them to ride their bikes. Tickets for the event will be available from April 19, with the attempt being broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, described her challenging match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as an "eye-opener" as the claycourt season begins. Despite eventually winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, Williams acknowledged she was not as prepared for the clay season as she had thought. The United States team, including Williams and Alison Riske, lost to Italy 3-2 in the Fed Cup, resulting in their relegation to World Group II after a doubles defeat. Williams emphasized the need to adjust her mindset and be ready for more shots on clay. The loss also marked the first blemish on Williams' otherwise perfect Fed Cup record. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez stressed the need for harder work to return to the World Group.

River Plate is interested in signing Radamel Falcao, their former striker who is currently on loan at Manchester United. Falcao, who spent eight years with River Plate before moving to Porto in 2009, has struggled at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals this season. Despite this, River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's desire to have Falcao back, stating, "We dream of Falcao Garcia. The doors are open." Falcao has been in good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games to tie Colombia’s all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. During his time at River Plate, Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has partnered with dry shampoo brand Batiste for their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson with various hairstyles against a vibrant city background and includes a TV advertising campaign with her latest single, Mirror Man. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency, and Henderson expressed her excitement about working with the brand, which she uses regularly. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, highlighted the natural synergies between Henderson and Batiste.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, a 26-year-old man shot dead by police officer Pablo Torres on March 14 in Kenosha, Wisconsin, are in shock and angered by a billboard erected by the Kenosha Professional Police Association. The billboard features Torres and his dog, with a message thanking the community for its support. Siler's family and friends find the billboard disrespectful, with one family friend stating it felt like a thank you for killing Aaron. The police association claims no offense was intended and that the billboard was meant to express gratitude for community support. Siler was wanted on an active felony probation and parole warrant and was shot following a vehicle and foot pursuit. This incident occurred just 10 days after Torres shot 66-year-old Terry Knight, who was armed with two knives. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, while the shooting of Knight was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border in the town of Negur. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces, while Iranian officials requested Pakistani authorities to capture the surviving assailants. The militant group Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian group from Balochistan, Pakistan, claimed responsibility for the attack. The Pakistani government condemned the attack and pledged to apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistan. This is not the first attack by Jaish al Adal, which has targeted Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan.

In a recent Japanese parliamentary session, former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki questioned whether Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) had ever encountered extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Defense Minister Gen Nakatani responded that while the ASDF scrambles fighter jets for visual observation when detecting potential airspace violations, they have never found a UFO believed to have come from outer space, only birds or other terrestrial flying objects. Inoki, known for his wrestling career, political endeavors, and various humanitarian missions, also shared that he has personally seen a UFO but is uncertain about the existence of aliens. This discussion echoes a 2007 debate on the legal implications of defending against an extraterrestrial invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after the toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China, broke and fell. Jin Pai was concerned about the cleanliness of the toilet seat and chose to stand on the rim instead. The toilet unexpectedly collapsed, causing severe injuries that required several dozen stitches. Initially, Jin Pai claimed he was squatting, but later changed his story to the police, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities considered the incident an accident and reminded the public that the toilets are intended for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The investigation started when the girl found the hidden camera in March. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera, 34 of which showed victims showering. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and had purchased the camera specifically to record the now-15-year-old victim. His preliminary hearing is on May 1, and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of images featuring daughters standing po-faced while their fathers leap dramatically into the air. The daughters wear casual clothing, while the fathers are dressed in sharp suits, reflecting the concept of "salary man." The series, part of Aoyama's book roughly translating to "Daughter and Salaryman," aims to showcase fathers expressing their fun side through energetic poses. Despite some fathers appearing slightly pained, the images have garnered significant online interest for their unique and curious nature. The photographs are set against various Japanese landmarks.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and its implications for Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England cricket team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, is now with Surrey and is aiming to force his way back into the Test set-up. The focus has shifted to the start of the county championship season, with Pietersen participating in a team photo shoot at the KIA Oval. Despite looking deep in thought during the photo shoot, Pietersen was in a jovial mood, joking with photographers and teammates. His last appearance at the international level was during the disastrous Ashes tour in Australia the previous year. Surrey's first match of the season is against Glamorgan on April 19, and they will also play Oxford MCCU in an MCC University match on Sunday.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, facing relegation, has dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps, was initially fired due to poor performance but reinstated by owner Angelo Massone. However, after Ceahlaul lost 2-0 to FC Botosani, leaving them 16th in the standings and six points from safety, Ze Maria was again sacked. He had been Ceahlaul's third coach of the season, replacing Florin Marin in January, and will now be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao must regret his failed loan move to Manchester United, despite being unhappy in France. Falcao, a former Atletico Madrid striker, moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan but has struggled to match his previous performance levels due to a serious knee injury. Manchester United would need to pay £46 million to make Falcao's transfer permanent, but with only four goals scored this season, they are unlikely to exercise that option. Dirar revealed that Falcao was not content in France and suggests he would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played and participated in the Champions League.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy while wearing a distinctive cartoon mask. The suspect, captured on security footage, was wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and the mask, and is described as very tall. He stole the dairy's till and approximately $1,500 in cash. The incident occurred on Saturday at the Union St dairy in east Christchurch, where the masked man demanded cash from the owner's daughter. The daughter ran out screaming "robber!" after the man threw the cash register to the ground. Although no weapons were used, the robber remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested on March 19 for having an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, involving kissing and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail. Granado was arrested again on March 24 after another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January, in her car near another school in Dallas. She was booked into Irving County Jail for the second time and released after posting a $50,000 bail. Granado has been suspended from teaching and placed on administrative leave by school officials.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws has garnered over 500,000 views online. The incident occurred while New Zealand tourist Tim Weston was on holiday with his wife. The dog, belonging to a local bike shop owner, approached the water's edge out of curiosity, leading to the crocodile's attack. The crocodile held the dog for hours, causing shock among onlookers. Crocodiles are common in the area due to the resort's location among mangroves, and they are often seen near the marina and on the golf course.

Steve Bruce remains confident that Hull City can avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, which leaves them just two points above the drop zone. Initially aiming for 10 wins to secure their position, Hull have only managed six wins so far. Bruce believes that nine or eight wins might still be enough to stay up. Hull have six games remaining, including challenging matches against top teams like Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes Hull's struggles to long-term injuries of key players, such as Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton's victory, secured by a James Ward-Prowse penalty and a late goal from Graziano Pelle, moved them to fifth in the table. Southampton's manager, Ronald Koeman, also had to address an internal issue when Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty against team protocol.

A teacher named Ian Guffick was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. This led to the annulment of the school's SATs results for 2014. Guffick admitted to altering some answers himself and asked students to make changes to their answers, despite the exam session finishing. The National College for Teaching and Leadership panel found his conduct to be dishonest but not amounting to fraud or serious dishonesty. Guffick expressed deep regret for his actions.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has had limited playing time but enjoys a happy personal life with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri. They married in a beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together. Despite his struggles on the pitch, Lindegaard frequently shares his personal life on Instagram, including moments with Beqiri. Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, is also active on Instagram, often posting modeling photos. Lindegaard has been with Beqiri since 2012 and has made only 19 league appearances for Manchester United since joining in 2010. Currently, he is third-choice goalkeeper at Old Trafford.

The glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite estimates of $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid, for $260,000, came from a Sotheby's employee. The current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, purchased the letters after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson expressed a desire for a new generation to own the iconic letters, which had been above the stadium since 1976. At the same auction, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s sold for $112,500, exceeding its estimated value of $20,000 to $30,000.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe regarding their recent behavior, emphasizing their professional responsibilities without imposing disciplinary actions. Sterling, who will play in the FA Cup semi-final due to Daniel Sturridge's injury, was seen inhaling nitrous oxide and using shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to the players and aims to move past the incident. He highlighted the importance of understanding the responsibilities that come with being a professional athlete. Rodgers also mentioned that Steven Gerrard is available for the FA Cup semi-final after serving a suspension, but he has not disclosed whether Gerrard will be included in the lineup. Rodgers' main focus is on guiding Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and shared a picture of himself relaxing with his dog, captioned "Home Sweet Home." He performed well for Germany in their 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Despite missing Arsenal's last game against Newcastle due to illness, Ozil is expected to start against Liverpool. Since January, he has contributed four assists and scored three goals. Ozil feels he is adjusting well to English football, appreciating the frequent matches and the recovery breaks.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the La Liga leaders have no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, expressing that the club is "very happy" with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer and signed a two-year deal, is currently six games away from potentially winning the title. Despite speculation about his replacement, Bartomeu refuted these claims, highlighting Enrique's dedication and the team's capability to win multiple trophies. The manager's efforts were evident in the preparation for the Champions League game against PSG and the subsequent match against Valencia, where goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi secured a win.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, providing a boost after their FA Cup defeat. The vice-captain, who had 14 months left on his current deal, will sign improved terms worth around £100,000 per week, extending his stay until 2020. This makes him the third significant player in Brendan Rodgers' squad to commit to a new contract, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson, who joined Liverpool in 2011 for £16 million from Sunderland, has significantly improved under Rodgers and is being considered for the club captaincy when Steven Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume at the end of the season, although he has rejected a new deal for now.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his three-year contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. He has struggled to secure the left back position at Stamford Bridge. Luis expressed his happiness at Chelsea and commitment to fulfilling his contract. After playing for Brazil in friendly matches against France and Chile, his focus now shifts to the Premier League title run-in, with Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho emphasizing the importance of winning every game. Luis acknowledged the difficulty of their remaining nine games but expressed confidence in the team's preparedness.

Nathan Hughes' ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal. Initially suspended for three matches for being reckless, the ban was rescinded following Wasps' appeal and public outcry. Hughes' knee collided with North's head as he scored a try, leading to North's unconsciousness and a three-month recovery period. Despite no intent, Hughes was initially sanctioned but the appeal panel concluded the incident was accidental. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final but is now free to play.

Seattle native Tim Durkan photographed fiery sunsets in Washington, sharing them on CNN iReport. These stunning sunsets were caused by wildfires in Siberia, which started when farmers burned grass in their fields. Strong winds caused the flames to spread, destroying dozens of villages. The smoke from these fires traveled across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, resulting in intense red sunsets as smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange hues to dominate. As the smoke dissipates, the fiery sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig, a Missouri mom, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was later found and returned by police after a tip from a man who recognized it. Upon retrieval, Schoenig found that the thieves had added red rims, red detailing, and orange accents to the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, she humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook and plans to clean the car professionally to remove the smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Schoenig also plans to create a special smoothie, "The Sexton on Wheels," at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who helped locate her car.

Manchester City players, including stars like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, face losing £500,000 in bonuses each if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. The Premier League title holders have incentivized contracts for their star players to comply with financial fairplay rules, putting around £12 million in total bonuses at risk. Currently in fourth place, City's European hopes are precarious, with Liverpool only four points behind and able to surpass them if they win their upcoming match. The top three Premier League finishers qualify automatically for the Champions League, with the fourth-place team needing to win a qualifying round. City manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged the team's poor performance in the last three months, which has jeopardized their season and Champions League qualification.

In a 'mini-derby' match, Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal via a delightful free-kick. The match, held at Altrincham's Moss Lane, saw a predominantly English lineup with 13 out of 22 players being English, including 10 Mancunians. The game, which had free entry, attracted nearly 1,000 spectators. Despite the casual setting, the match was competitive, with City's Marcus Wood nearly scoring with an audacious chip. Marcus Rashford missed two chances for United. The victory places United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough, while City, hampered by injuries, have lost both their matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. The match highlighted potential homegrown talent that could feature in the first team in the future.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised fellow goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who achieved his own milestone of 50 caps during the match, expressed admiration for Buffon's continued success at 37 years old and stated that he still has much to learn from him. Hart also shared his pride in reaching 50 caps and his desire to continue playing for both his club and country.

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant, has entered the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver burritos to customers' doors in 67 cities. The collaboration includes a nine percent service charge, with Postmates delivery fees starting at $5 and varying based on distance and demand. Chipotle previously declined other third-party delivery service offers but has now partnered with Postmates, which employs independent contractors driving their own cars, similar to Uber taxis. The fast-casual chain has seen growth in recent years, with notable customers such as presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton. Other franchises, including Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, are also exploring or implementing delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have made a public plea to the Justice Department to remove the death penalty as a potential punishment for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all charges related to the bombings. In an opinion piece in The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard detailed the profound impact the tragedy has had on their family, including the death of their 8-year-old son and severe injuries to their daughter. Despite acknowledging the brutality of the crimes, they argue that pursuing the death penalty could lead to years of appeals and further trauma for their surviving children. Instead, they support life imprisonment without parole for Tsarnaev, in exchange for waiving his right to appeal, to bring closure and allow their family and the community to move forward.

An enormous Boeing 747-8 has been transformed into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire, costing an estimated £400 million. Custom-built over three years to the owner's specifications, the jet features bedrooms, multiple lounges, an onboard restaurant, a conference room, and an 'aeroloft' with eight full beds. The interior, designed to resemble a luxury hotel, includes a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a lounge, and a 'state room'. The plane, originally designed to carry up to 600 passengers, is now tailored for a single tycoon and can accommodate several dozen guests.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station from Cape Canaveral, Florida. Although the ascent and Dragon's journey to the ISS were successful, the attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge failed as the rocket tipped over. This was the sixth SpaceX mission to the ISS, and the second attempt for this particular mission after a previous launch was scrubbed due to weather. The Dragon will deliver supplies, including an ISSpresso machine, and return with science experiments and waste. SpaceX aims to reduce space access costs by reusing rockets.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding in the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, which is part of the Westgate Hotel. NBC's Today show collaborated with Priscilla to host a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win a "ultimate wedding" at the chapel on April 23. The winners, to be announced next Monday, will receive a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla emphasized that the event is first-class and not a joke, with no impersonators allowed. Couples interested in the contest must submit a video or photos with an explanation of why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, despite being four points behind. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season in a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, equaling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues this campaign. Liverpool found winning form again after poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Manchester City has been faltering, losing 4-2 to Manchester United. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored in the 2-0 win over Newcastle, with Allen capitalizing on a defensive mistake for his first Anfield goal.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, thanks to a goal by Miralem Pjanic in the 25th minute. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made crucial saves in the second half to secure the win. The victory moved Roma four points ahead of city rivals Lazio and extended Napoli's winless streak to five matches. Security was tight for the match due to past incidents, but there were no reported problems. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho.

Doncaster Rovers had an uninspired season in League One, settling into mid-table mediocrity. Their recent match against Fleetwood Town ended in a 0-0 draw, making it challenging for the media team to compile engaging highlights. Consequently, they uploaded a 27-second video to the club's YouTube channel, featuring only 14 seconds of match action: the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, which he interacts with through touch despite it being a marine pet. He gently strokes and massages the fish, which responds by relaxing and enjoying the sensation. Initially, the fish would swim away but eventually returned for more interaction. Giroux removed the other fish from the tank due to bullying and began hand-feeding the cichlid frozen blood worms, leading to increased sociability. The fish now enjoys daily 15-minute sessions of being stroked and massaged, even showing signs of frustration if not interacted with regularly. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid breed first developed in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes is known for his fiery character and aggression in the England cricket team. He broke his wrist punching a locker after being dismissed last year, which serves as a reminder to channel his aggression appropriately. Stokes clashed with Marlon Samuels during a Test match but responded positively after a talk with England coach Peter Moores. England's coach believes Stokes' natural exuberance and desire to take on opponents should be nurtured, but his aggression must be controlled. Stokes' aggression can contribute to runs and wickets for the team, and England aims to have him play as much as possible to help him reach his full potential. The team wants both Stokes and Chris Jordan to play frequently, even though there might be a need for only one spinner during the summer.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12 has sold out with 33,000 tickets sold. Both teams are tied at the top of Group B with 11 points each, though Belgium leads on goal difference. Wales is in its best position to qualify for a major tournament since the 1958 World Cup. The match follows Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel, which has heightened expectations for Chris Coleman's team. The Football Association of Wales reported overwhelming demand for tickets. Despite speculation, UEFA rules prevented changing the venue to the larger Millennium Stadium. The Wales squad prefers playing at the Cardiff City Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, with the Young Lions as defending champions. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, who is called up for the first time. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have returned to the squad. England is in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, starting their campaign against Italy on May 7.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht midfielder Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth academy. Patoulidis has also caught the attention of Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously declined a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his studies. Manchester City has discussed a potential compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock. Manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure Patoulidis for the future.

A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, who was found strangled and beaten in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. Santillan was pronounced dead at the scene from injuries to her head and neck. The suspect has been bailed and is due to return for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for information from anyone who may have had contact with Santillan before her death. Santillan worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, though police have not confirmed if her profession is central to the investigation. Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves is leading the investigation and urges anyone who saw Santillan on the Friday or Saturday before her death to come forward.

Dawn, a woman who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to accuse her family friend Jamie, a convicted burglar, of stealing £207 she had saved for a gravestone for her baby. After a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, Dawn became emotional and left the show. Jamie had previously sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing to taking the money and blaming it on his girlfriend, Carol. Dawn expressed her distress and feeling of betrayal over the theft.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group from northern Iraq, who were previously killed, captured, and displaced by the terror organization. Most of the released individuals were women and children, with the rest being ill or elderly. The release was coordinated with the help of Arab tribal leaders, though the exact motivation remains unclear. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil, the Kurdish regional capital. This release follows previous instances where ISIS freed other Yazidis, predominantly children and the elderly. The Yazidis, an ancient religious community of Kurdish descent, have faced significant persecution, including being referred to as devil worshipers by many Muslims. ISIS's actions against the Yazidis have been particularly brutal, leading to a humanitarian crisis and prompting international intervention, including airstrikes by the U.S. and its allies.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham striker, has had an exceptional season, breaking into the first team and the England side. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animation by Copa90 showcases Kane's best goals and celebrations from the season, including his long-range strike against Chelsea, a headed goal against Arsenal, and his England debut goal. The video, titled "Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?", was released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane is competing against players like Chelsea's Eden Hazard and Arsenal's Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right person to lead Liverpool forward despite a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, emphasized that Rodgers' future should not be determined by one game and highlighted the challenges of integrating new players. Liverpool is currently seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City and is likely to miss out on Champions League qualification. Carragher expressed confidence that Rodgers, the players, and the staff will focus on next season with the aim of winning a trophy and securing a top-four finish. He also stressed the importance of making the right signings to improve the team. Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, has been involved in coaching in eight schools in deprived areas of Merseyside through his foundation.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport, which was deemed a security risk by airport security. The plastic nerf gun, packed in his hand luggage, was taken from him after being flagged on the X-ray machines. James was also frisked by security officers, an action criticized by his father, Phil, as "over-zealous" and "ludicrous." The family was late for their flight to Lanzarote and couldn't argue with the security staff. Upon returning from their holiday, they bought James a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their actions, stating that the safety and security of passengers is their priority and that regulations prohibit items resembling prohibited items.

A 31-year-old man named Rich, living in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He detailed his ideal partner as someone who loves pets, is non-drinking, non-smoking, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, skilled with their hands, a good cook, and great in bed. He also mentioned that the successful candidate would enjoy the outdoors and be versatile, acting as a "princess when needed." Rich described himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, brown-haired, brown-eyed, and independent, with a love for traveling, sports, fishing, and camping. He offered potential benefits such as accommodation, a company car, phone, laptop, a free gym membership, and other perks. Rich emphasized that he is willing to spend money on his woman and that all reasonable offers would be considered, but former partners need not apply. Attempts to contact Rich by Daily Mail Australia were unsuccessful.

Football Association (FA) chairman Greg Dyke is seeking to implement significant changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12, and to redefine "home-grown" players as those who have trained in England for three years before the age of 18 instead of before 21. Despite facing opposition from the Premier League, Dyke has received support from five former England managers: Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren. In a letter to Dyke, these managers warn that the English game will suffer if Dyke's proposals are blocked, emphasizing the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level and the need for more opportunities for young players. They highlight the emergence of promising young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane as evidence that England can still produce top talent.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, is now the proud mother to the show's latest addition, with fans seeing Aidan Turner's Ross Poldark gazing lovingly at their new baby daughter within ten minutes of the next episode. Despite Ross marrying Demelza out of duty, his feelings for her are evident. However, the timeline of Demelza's pregnancy has raised questions, as she goes from barely showing to being eight months pregnant and giving birth within a short span in the show. This fast-paced pregnancy has drawn comparisons to a previous one in the series and has been noted by fans on social media.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to maintain focus and avoid distractions from their relegation rivals as they sit just three points from safety in the Premier League. After back-to-back wins, including a last-minute 3-2 victory against West Bromwich Albion with Jamie Vardy scoring the winning goal, Leicester remains at the bottom of the table. Pearson emphasized that the team's future is in their own hands and advised against getting overly optimistic, stressing the importance of concentrating on their own performance in the remaining games.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest migration of a mammal, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's migration included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale rather than the endangered western gray whale previously thought. This discovery could impact the estimated population of western gray whales, which is believed to be around 150.

Residents on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island experienced an unexpected emergence of 1,000 feet of seabed on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, rising up to 50 feet above sea level. This new stretch of coastline, approximately 1,000 to 1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide, appeared overnight and surprised locals who reported no sounds or tremors. Geologists attribute the phenomenon to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which pivoted the underwater area into the air. Authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further and believe it is unrelated to the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in the Kathmandu Valley.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer, expressing his love for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League match against Chelsea, Van der Wiel insists he is happy at PSG and has no plans to leave. He aims to sign a new contract and remains ready to play when called upon. However, PSG's interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves could impact Van der Wiel's future with the club.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus this summer to return to his former club, Boca Juniors in Argentina. Although his contract with Juventus runs until the end of the next season, Boca Juniors has confirmed they are close to finalizing a deal for the 31-year-old striker. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, emphasized that Tevez must terminate his contract with Juventus before the move can be completed. Tevez, who is on course to win a second Serie A title with Juventus and still has a chance at European glory, has always stated his intention to finish his career at Boca Juniors. Despite Juventus' reluctance to lose their top scorer, they have accepted Tevez's desire to leave and have begun identifying potential replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that any potential move would not affect the player's future with the Argentina national team.

During Bayern Munich's 6-1 victory over Porto in the Champions League, manager Pep Guardiola accidentally ripped a hole in his trousers, exposing his underwear. The match saw Bayern leading 5-0 at half-time, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Despite Porto entering the match with a two-goal lead from their previous encounter, Bayern's dominant performance booked them a place in the Champions League semi-finals. Guardiola humorously remarked about needing to buy new trousers for the next match.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale. Three cars collided on Wednesday afternoon. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were flown to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest injuries, while a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl were also airlifted with arm and abdominal pain, respectively. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries. One person was trapped in their vehicle and had to be freed by emergency crews using hydraulic cutting gear. The highway was closed for several hours with diversions in place.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil is excited for the upcoming Premier League match against Chelsea, having recently purchased an Apple Watch, which he compared to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. Ozil shared his excitement on Instagram. Arsenal, currently trailing Chelsea by 10 points with six games left, has been boosted by the return of midfielder Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench for the FA Cup semi-final win over Reading. Club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's fitness is key to reaching his potential.

Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford. Despite having sent off three players from both teams this season, including City captain Vincent Kompany, Clattenburg has only issued two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to United players. The match is crucial as United are a point ahead of City, potentially deciding the second place behind Chelsea. United have won their last five consecutive league games, while City have struggled, falling to fourth place. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter has accused the Queensland Government of holding racial prejudices against embattled MP Billy Gordon, referring to him as a 'little black puppet on a string'. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, believes the Government expected Gordon to resign after being accused of domestic violence and admitting to a criminal past. Gordon left the Queensland Labor Party but remains in the Queensland parliament as an independent, causing chaos for the Government. Katter's statement has faced criticism on social media, but he defended his choice of words, citing his personal experiences with racism.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using dance videos to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment due to her disability, she aims to show that she is just like anyone else and can achieve many things, including dancing and driving. Dayna hopes her videos and motivational speaking at local schools will encourage people to look past her disability and see her as an individual.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a large Latin-American fanbase, has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, are also interested in the Mexican forward. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a new contract offer to their young talent, Andreas Pereira, who has caught the attention of several European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord, after rejecting United's initial offer.

A gang of at least three people set a car on fire at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles early Saturday morning. The driver, who had an argument with the suspects while pumping gas, reported that the suspects attempted to carjack him and later poured gasoline on his white Dodge Charger, igniting it while two passengers were inside. Although the car was completely destroyed, no one was injured. The suspects remain at large, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, using surveillance video as part of their investigation.

A chiropractor from southern Iowa, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Manuel admitted to his misdeeds and agreed not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite these issues, he received outstanding patient satisfaction evaluations on HealthGrades.com. The revocation of his license was due to circumstances including bartering sex for services and recommending patients stop taking prescribed medication. Manuel has not commented on the case, and his former practice reported that he hadn't worked there for some time.

The United States has lodged a complaint with Russia after a Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner." The incident occurred in international airspace north of Poland, with the U.S. crew citing aggressive maneuvers and high speed by the Russian pilot. Russia claimed the U.S. plane had its transponder off and was flying toward their border, which the U.S. denied. This follows a similar incident a year ago in the Sea of Okhotsk, where a Russian jet came within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U, prompting a previous complaint from the Pentagon. Encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are common in Northern Europe and the area between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, was forcibly removed by breaking the car's rear right passenger-side window and using a rope to pull the case out. Along with the rifle, the agent's gear bag, backpack, and some clothing and tools were also stolen. Evidence such as skid marks, pieces of rope, and the broken handle of the rifle case were found at the scene. The rifle has not been recovered, but its serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was notified of the theft before President Obama's visit, though it is unclear if this prompted increased security measures. The hotel, located next to the city's airport and near the state's FBI office, lacks surveillance cameras.

In July 2012, Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor Terrence Freebody in the dining room of his home in Red Hill, Canberra. Costa allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and believes there was evidence of Costa's declining mental state due to dementia and alcohol abuse both before and during the incident. The jury's decision may hinge on whether Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

In a 1-0 win against Burnley at Goodison Park, Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended a penalty situation where Ross Barkley missed from the spot in the 10th minute. Barkley took the penalty, awarded for a foul by David Jones on Aaron Lennon, despite Leighton Baines being on the pitch. Baines has a strong record, having scored 15 out of 16 penalties in the Premier League. Although there was no dispute between the players, this incident recalled a previous match against West Brom in January when Kevin Mirallas took a penalty from Baines and missed. Martinez supported Barkley's decision to take the penalty, stating that multiple players can take penalties depending on their feelings at the moment. Barkley's shot was well-struck but saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton. The match's only goal was scored by Mirallas in the 29th minute.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, which appears to be a murder-suicide, according to Holland America Line. The cruise line secured the cabin and notified authorities, including the FBI, who are currently investigating. The ship departed from Tampa, Florida, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The deceased passengers were discovered by the cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin's door.

Patrick Kluivert, a former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup in CONCACAF. Curacao advanced by drawing 2-2 against Montserrat in the second leg, resulting in a 4-3 aggregate win. Kluivert's team had previously won 2-1 in the first leg. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, has experience as a World Cup semi-finalist in 1998 and as an assistant coach in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan and Real Madrid midfielder with 15 major trophies, joined Leicester City in the summer. Despite Leicester being at the bottom of the Premier League table with only eight games left, Cambiasso believes they can avoid relegation and considers it a significant achievement akin to winning a trophy. He remains optimistic about Leicester's chances and is content with his time at the club, hinting at the possibility of extending his stay beyond his current one-year contract.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma, who has two children under five by different fathers, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children by her 52-year-old mother, Debbie. Gemma handed her children over to Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie, who has been raising the children, is threatening to ban Gemma from seeing them due to Gemma's drinking, partying, use of legal highs, and suspected theft. Debbie claims Gemma is unfit to care for the children and has stolen an iPad from one of them. Gemma admits to stealing money and items from Debbie in the past but denies stealing the iPad. Debbie, who appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show with Gemma, is preparing to ban Gemma from her home and from seeing the children because she cannot trust Gemma not to steal from them.

During a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored a goal following a controversial incident. Chelsea captain John Terry delivered a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, which led to a loose ball collected by Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas. Fabregas passed the ball to Oscar, who back-heeled it to Hazard for the goal. Sky Sports pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry, and Jamie Redknapp agreed during their half-time analysis that Terry's challenge on Falcao should have been penalized as a foul.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 in Texas, but all passengers were safely evacuated. Michael Barnett captured the incident on video and uploaded it to CNN iReport. The fire started after a rear tire blew out on the bus. Hillary Scott confirmed on Instagram that she, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver were unharmed. The fire destroyed the back lounge of the bus except for Scott's Bible. The band's other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus at the time. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing a space laser system that converts sunlight into energy using satellites covered in mirrors. This energy is then shot back to Earth to power homes, potentially making solar power viable in Scotland or restoring power in disaster-hit areas. Unlike movie depictions, these lasers won't be powerful enough to cause harm. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, with plans to move to Portugal. This system differs from a Tokyo research proposal to use lasers on the International Space Station to clear space debris. Dr. Quarterman acknowledges the need for control over who operates these satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a "fanatical obsession" with young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. Munden, who was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus, was last seen leaving the hospital at 6.15pm on Tuesday. Authorities have launched a manhunt for him, noting that he may have shaved off his beard and describing him as 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, and with dark hair. Munden was convicted of sexually touching a child under 13 and had admitted to ten unrelated offences of possessing or attempting to possess indecent images of children. He was detained at a private facility under a hospital order following his sentencing last August.

V. Stiviano, a former companion of Donald Sterling, has been ordered by a Los Angeles judge to repay over $2.6 million in gifts after Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling sued her. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men, claiming that Donald Sterling used their money to buy Stiviano a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with the gifts and that she never took advantage of Donald Sterling. The court's decision was seen as a victory for the Sterling family, as it set a precedent for the injured spouse to recover damages from the recipient of such gifts. The gifts from Donald Sterling also included various other items such as a $391 Easter bunny costume, a $299 two-speed blender, and a $12 lace thong. Donald Sterling's downfall came after an audio recording of him making racist remarks surfaced, leading to his ban from the NBA, a $2.5 million fine, and the termination of his ownership rights in the Clippers franchise.

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged the club to sign four top players in the summer to have a chance at winning the Premier League title. He emphasized the need for a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker. Henry specifically questioned whether Olivier Giroud could lead Arsenal to victory, despite his 14 league goals this season, suggesting that Arsenal would struggle to win the league with Giroud as the primary striker. He referenced Chelsea's successful signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example of the type of acquisitions Arsenal should aim for.

A young woman, a victim of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact the abuse had on her life. Van Ryn has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who cannot be named, expressed fear for her future relationships and questioned why she was targeted. She revealed that she didn't understand the abuse was wrong or illegal when it happened and only broke her silence after learning Van Ryn had been caught. The victim also shared that she has suffered from depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide since the age of 14.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, is recovering from a serious knee injury that sidelined him since March 2014. He impressed for the Gunners before the injury but has since played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading, signaling his return to form. Gnabry reports feeling "better and better" and is looking forward to his next game.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, accidentally fell to his death from a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales, after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. Phillips, who had been out with friends, didn't have enough cash to pay the cab fare and decided to flee in the dark. He became disoriented and leapt over a fence, plunging down the cliff. His body was found the next day by a dog walker. The coroner concluded that Phillips' death was accidental, as there was no evidence he knew the danger he was in. Phillips worked for the clothing label Pretty Green and had been staying with his mother in Cowbridge during the Christmas period.

Last summer, thousands of holidaymakers affected by passport delays did not receive compensation, despite the HM Passport Office making a £42 million profit during the chaos. Managers at the passport agency received bonuses up to £3,500. Ministers refused to provide a blanket refund to families who paid extra for fast-track services or missed trips. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, with an average payout of £92.68. Keith Vaz, chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, expressed astonishment at the low number of compensations given. The office struggled to manage 3.6 million applications, leading to over half a million passports stuck in the system by mid-June.

A timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s, is up for sale with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. The semi-detached property features original elements such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, vintage cupboards, and a mint green and black bathroom. The house includes original kitchen cupboards, a brick open-face fire, and a dated kitchen sink. A hallway shelf holds original tins of produce like Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk and Tate and Lyle sugar. Although double-glazed, the potential renovation costs might deter developers, making it ideal for antique enthusiasts. The house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in mid-2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, lived in Texas and San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) in Secaucus to NY 495 in the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, offering access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, specifically NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed the band Blur. Blur's debut album, Leisure, was released in 1991. Albarn's self-titled debut solo album, Everyday Robots, was released on 28 April 2014, featuring collaborations with notable artists and choirs, and samples from Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also known locally as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. It is the location of many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP), Broken, which was released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The passage describes two adaptations of the character Bob Lee Swagger: a marksman and Force Recon veteran. In the 2007 film "Shooter," Mark Wahlberg plays Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue private military company. In the TV series "Shooter," Ryan Phillippe stars as Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who returns to action upon learning of a plot to kill the president.
"House" (also known as "House, M.D.") is an American medical drama TV series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, starting on November 16, 2004, and ending on May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, carried out by his group. He also received convictions for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After being charged, recordings of his songs were released commercially.

Sean Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He started his acting career in television with a brief appearance in "Little House on the Prairie" (1974), directed by his father. Penn made his film debut in "Taps" (1981) and gained critical attention for roles in "At Close Range" (1986), "State of Grace" (1990), and "Carlito's Way" (1993). He became a prominent leading actor with "Dead Man Walking" (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two more Oscar nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" (1999) and "I Am Sam" (2001), winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for "Mystic River" and a second one in 2008 for "Milk".

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, AC (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001), known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring from playing, he remained influential in the sport as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.

L.A. Reid has held significant leadership roles in the music industry, including serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (Sony Music Entertainment), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991. As of 2016, he has been playing with Prophets of Rage, which includes members from Rage Against the Machine, Public Enemy, and Cypress Hill. Additionally, Rage is a separate German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015. It consisted of 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS announced the cancellation of the show on November 14, 2014, during the second season, after airing four episodes.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (September 1, 1933 – September 13, 2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. A Democrat, she gained national attention as Texas state treasurer by delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Richards served as Texas governor until her defeat for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. She was the second female governor of Texas, known for her outspoken feminism and memorable one-liners.
Drake Bell released an independently produced EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, was born Jeanette Helen Morrison on July 6, 1927, and passed away on October 3, 2004. She also authored four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader born on 24 July 1783 and died on 17 December 1830. He played a key role in the independence of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, also known as the Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starter in mid-2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the 49ers to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In the 2013 season, his first full season as a starter, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
"Marnie" is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a nonpersonal, openly sponsored message used to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain's al-Wefaq party, emphasized the necessity of national dialogue for meaningful progress, urging the government to present concrete solutions. The United States has suspended its participation in bilateral talks with Russia aimed at sustaining the cessation of hostilities in Syria, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks against civilians in Aleppo. The US had warned it would halt the talks unless Moscow stopped bombing Aleppo. Russia expressed regret over the US decision, accusing Washington of shifting the blame for the collapse of the truce. The US cited Russia's failure to ensure Syrian regime adherence to the truce and targeting of critical infrastructure, including hospitals, as reasons for the suspension. Russia denies involvement in the attack on a humanitarian aid convoy and claims the incident was due to fire on the ground. The US also withdrew personnel dispatched for a potential Joint Implementation Centre in anticipation of the talks. His mother reported that he saw a GP for the rash but was found dead the next morning. In a closely contested National League match, Guiseley and Gateshead played to a 1-1 draw. Guiseley took an early lead in the 15th minute through Jake Lawlor, but Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute with a goal from Wesley York. Both teams made several substitutions throughout the match, and there were yellow cards issued to Simon Walton (Guiseley) and Gus Mafuta (Gateshead). The result maintains Guiseley's nine-match unbeaten streak in the National League, while Gateshead remains unbeaten in their last five matches. The match report was supplied by the Press Association.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands to increase the capacity of the football club's stadium, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed. The majority shareholder, Steve Lansdown, confirmed the club's intention to begin work at a shareholder meeting. The work was approved by Bristol City Council in November. The club aims to sign the section 106 agreement and, if no judicial review occurs by March, will start the redevelopment in May.

Cuadrilla, the company conducting shale gas drilling (fracking) in Lancashire, has suspended operations following a 1.5 magnitude earthquake, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is examining the data and has noted that the latest tremor, centered on Poulton-le-Fylde, shares a similar location and mechanism with the April quake. Fracking involves breaking shale rocks to release gas and has been controversial, particularly in the US where environmental concerns have been raised. Cuadrilla's CEO, Mark Miller, stated that they are consulting with authorities and experts, and a decision on resuming operations will be made after several weeks. The BGS is also monitoring the situation and has acknowledged that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes. The April tremor occurred 1.2 miles from the drilling site, and the latest one is believed to have taken place at a depth of approximately 2km.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes while giving the impression he was collecting cash for the charity in April 2015. He was cleared of two other fraud counts. Carpenter, who usually wears a kilt and piper's regalia, claimed he was simply busking and the banner was a tribute to the victims. Kenneth Derbyshire, chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, had given Carpenter permission to display the banner but clarified it was not for collecting funds. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town secured a 3-0 victory over Queens Park Rangers (QPR) in a Championship match. Grant Ward's shot put Ipswich ahead, followed by Luke Varney's goal after QPR's Alex Smithies miscued a clearance. Tom Lawrence finished the scoring with a calm finish. QPR struggled in attack and had limited chances, with Sandro heading a corner against the post late in the game. Ipswich, who had failed to score in seven of their previous 10 Championship games, had several missed opportunities. The win lifted Ipswich to 14th place, while QPR slipped to 15th. Both managers, Mick McCarthy and Ian Holloway, commented on the match, with McCarthy praising his team's performance and Holloway emphasizing the need for mental toughness from his players.

Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, performed well in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's direction and praised the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams were praised for their leadership. The team's strong performance was attributed to their front row and front five making over 70 tackles. Despite the victory, Reds' coach Churcher emphasized the need for improvement and highlighted the emotionally driven, albeit not perfect, performance against Chinnor. The Reds' upcoming fixtures include matches against seven lower-ranked teams and league leaders Old Elthamians.

Police in India have arrested 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, a Bangladeshi citizen, for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town on 14 March. The arrest, made at a railway station in Kolkata, marks the sixth in connection with the crime. Authorities have identified eight suspects, with two still at large. The incident sparked outrage and protests across India. Nazrul was identified from CCTV footage and had fled to Bangladesh before his return to Kolkata. Earlier, Milon Sarkar was arrested as the alleged gang leader, though his specific role in the attack remains unclear. During the attack, money was stolen from the convent school, the building was ransacked, and the nun was raped in the convent.

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, who explains factors influencing consumer purchasing changes. These factors include the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video also examines shifts in ownership and rankings of major UK brands. It notes that the video may not function on older browsers and provides a non-interactive version. Additionally, it offers links to related content, including information on China's ownership, tips on freezing food, and a survey ranking the top 20 consumer brands in the UK. The video is recommended to be viewed in full screen.

Two incidents of scams involving individuals pretending to be from BT technical support have been reported. In the first incident, a 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked on 15 September. In the second incident, a woman in Stranraer lost money seven days later on 22 September. In both cases, the scammers gained remote access to the victims' computers. PC Siobhan Pellett emphasized the frightening ease with which scammers gain access and the substantial sums taken, urging people to be cautious with cold calls requesting remote computer access and to never share banking details over the phone. Banks and reputable businesses never ask for such information.
