Duffy, a 37-year-old former player for Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has signed a one-year contract with the third-placed Championship team, Featherstone, after his tenure as Scotland assistant coach and leaving Swinton Lions. He will manage Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy's work at Swinton, noting his success in challenging conditions. Duffy's position at Swinton has been filled by his former assistant, Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, along with a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The rider, who had sustained head injuries and was very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand, was treated by the crew before being transported to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to dedicate a radio frequency for global flight tracking via satellites, aiming to improve the current system that relies on ground-based radars and leaves 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. This decision was influenced by the disappearance of MH370 in March 2014. The new system will enable satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, allowing real-time tracking. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a deadline of November 2016 for adopting new tracking guidelines, which will require aircraft to send their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found at 18 living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, Julian's father, was arrested and is held at Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on charges of tampering with records and a $250,000 bail. The FBI, working with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, confirmed Julian's identity after a tip regarding his college application issues. Julian's mother has been notified of his recovery. Authorities had suspected Bobby around the time of Julian's 2002 disappearance when he claimed to be taking Julian to pre-school but then fled.

Following a blaze on 2 March at a site on Duncan Street, firefighters spent several days at the location, causing reduced train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste due to the incident. Although the firm was deemed "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, the EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, barring it from operating from the site. The company has the option to appeal the decision. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service had visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months, expressing concerns to the EA in February about potential fire impacts on residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two bills related to the situation in Ukraine, particularly focusing on the Crimea region where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill aims to allow Russia to accept territories from neighboring states that express a desire to join Russia, even if those states are disintegrating, bypassing the need for a treaty under existing law. The second bill expedites the process for issuing Russian passports to Russian-speaking Ukrainians, removing several requirements and significantly reducing the waiting period from a year to two months. This initiative is framed as support for the "fraternal people of Ukraine" facing a perceived threat. The bills reflect Russia's interest in extending its influence in regions with significant Russian populations or strategic importance, as seen in the cases of Abkhazia and South Ossetia following the 2008 war with Georgia.

McLaren, a team with a storied history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a slump, with their best possible grid position being the fourth row. The team's decline began in 2013 due to issues with chassis design, despite having the best engine. Although they have regained their form with the car, problems with the Honda power-unit persist. McLaren's most successful era was with Honda, achieving significant victories in the late 1980s and 1990s. Despite their current challenges, McLaren has two world champions in Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton, and team principal Ron Dennis remains optimistic about their future, believing they will break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again.

Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, was fatally shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January. The 44-year-old was found injured and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29, 29, and 32, have been arrested and are in police custody. Detectives believe the assailants had been waiting outside Phoenix Gym for about an hour. Authorities are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene and have urged several people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward as they may have crucial information.

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy Christmas online while maintaining a spiritual focus, avoiding the common issue of unworkable toys. It highlights five methods: 

1. **Everyday Church Online**: A virtual church offering services streamed online, with participants from 61 countries. It features a chat room and festive sermons themed around Star Wars.

2. **Guardians of Ancora**: A fantasy game aimed at children aged 8-11, developed by the Scripture Union, where players rediscover biblical stories to light up a dark world. Special Christmas content includes Bible-themed quests.

3. **Digital Nativity Videos**: Creative videos depicting the Christmas story through modern digital platforms like Facebook and Twitter, such as "The Digital Story of Nativity" and "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle."

4. **Next Manga's Manga Messiah**: An app and e-book retelling the nativity story in Manga form, available in 33 languages, aiming to share hope and peace, especially with refugees.

5. **Social Media Engagement**: Various Christian groups using platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to share spiritual thoughts and connect with their communities during the festive season.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is assessing a proposal to develop over 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land. Supporters, including Blaenau Gwent council, have proposed around 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land. Experts have conflicting views on whether the development would harm habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it difficult to conclude that the replacement land is of equal value but does not oppose the development overall. Developers claim a "net gain" in biodiversity due to nearby habitat enhancements, an assertion contested by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend a decision after the inquiry, with the final approval resting with Welsh government ministers.

Chechen Muslim clerics convened on 3 April, expressing outrage over a Novaya Gazeta report revealing the detention and alleged killing of over 100 individuals suspected of being homosexual in Chechnya. They issued a resolution calling for retribution against those responsible for the report, which Novaya Gazeta interpreted as a threat against its journalists. The paper emphasized the importance of preventing incitement of hatred towards journalists. The Russian LGBT Network corroborated the report, stating that detainees were tortured and that all those arrested were homosexual men or perceived as gay. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, while the Chechen spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, confirmed the call for retribution. Novaya Gazeta's editor pledged to continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya, despite the threats. The LGBT Network is assisting individuals fleeing Chechnya and plans to take action at the International Criminal Court if Russia does not prosecute the alleged abuses.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, has been receiving substantial benefit payments by housing single homeless men in properties, while Fresh Start Housing, a charity, finds clients from London homeless charities. Both entities operate from the same building in south London. Investing Solutions profits by placing multiple unrelated people in one house and claiming housing benefit for each person, resulting in a higher benefit payout than the rent fee passed to the landlord. Despite the legality of their actions, a homeless group criticizes this relationship as "a new low." Wandsworth Council has paid Investing Solutions over £2.1m in the past two years. Samir Patel, the founder of both Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing, maintains that Fresh Start is an independent charity and that the majority of rents go to private landlords.

In a closely contested game, London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 for Coach Joe Prunty's team. Despite leading for most of the first three quarters, GB was overtaken by the Netherlands in the final 10 minutes, losing the match. Prunty emphasized the importance of effort in the upcoming Eurobasket qualifiers, starting with a game in Hungary. The Netherlands, led by Worthy De Jong's 18 points, took an early fourth-quarter lead and held on to win the game. Prunty praised Gordon's performance, particularly his three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter.

The former five-weight world champion, Conor McGregor, submitted a necessary waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to use 8oz gloves for his upcoming fight against Floyd Mayweather, instead of the required 10oz gloves for a 154 lbs bout. The NAC will debate this matter on 16 August, with a focus on the health and safety of the fighters. Mayweather had previously stated his intention to use 8oz gloves but had not submitted the waiver. The NAC's executive director, Bob Bennett, expressed his approval for the fight, citing McGregor's skills and attributes. The bout, which could be the richest in history, has faced criticism from notable boxing personalities.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Dundee-based Sunday Post, reflect on the decline of Fleet Street, once synonymous with major British newspapers. The closure of the Sunday Post's London office marks the end of an era, as Fleet Street transitions from a hub of journalism to a collection of sandwich bars. Historically, Fleet Street was a pivotal location for the nation's biggest newspapers, with nearly every national paper and several provincial newspapers having offices nearby. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published there in 1702. The street was known for its many bars and pubs, frequented by journalists. However, the move of media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's papers to Wapping in 1986 and the adoption of new printing technology led to most national newspapers leaving Fleet Street by 1988. The buildings now serve other purposes, such as housing the headquarters of Sainsbury's supermarkets and a Pizza Express. The departure of the last two journalists from Fleet Street signifies the end of an infamous era in British history.

J.K. Rowling shared her experiences on Twitter, noting the prevalence of decent people despite encountering abusive comments. She expressed her stance against bullies and revealed she had been called "a traitor" for her political views, specifically her donation to the No vote campaign in the Scottish independence referendum. Rowling also mentioned interacting with supportive Scottish National Party (SNP) members and joked about bringing marshmallows after a suggestion to burn her books. The SNP became the third largest party in the UK following recent elections.

A study by the University of Edinburgh found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action compared to better-off children committing the same crime. Poverty increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts. Poorer young people are about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Household poverty is a significant factor in youth offending, even when other risk factors are considered. The study also found that people living in extreme poverty are more likely to be both victims and perpetrators of crime. The research tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 and was funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, the Nuffield Foundation, and the Scottish government. Despite the overall decrease in crime rates in Scotland, the study suggests that the most deprived communities continue to experience the highest rates of crime.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee early Sunday. Robbie Walsh from Kilrush was charged with assault causing serious harm and has been remanded in custody. Two other men arrested were released without charge, with files being sent to the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is alleged that Walsh and two others went to the Marian Estate looking for Mr. Haugh, resulting in a fight where Mr. Haugh was stabbed. Gardaí found knives and golf clubs at the scene. Mr. Haugh was taken to Limerick University Hospital where he died. Walsh is due to appear in court again on August 14.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted an allegation about Tom Elliott's past service in the UDR, claiming he harassed and shot people. Elliott, who served in the UDR from 1982 to 1992 and is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, has a clear Ministry of Defence record. The tweet was brought to Elliott's attention by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and is required to post an apology on Twitter, admitting the tweet was untrue and without foundation. The High Court is yet to decide on the compensation amount. Flanagan's insurance firm has refused to cover any compensation and costs, a decision Flanagan is challenging in a separate court action. Elliott expressed satisfaction with the vindication and disappointment over the prolonged process.

Hawick Knitwear, a company founded in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has increased its sweater production to 9,500 per week from 7,500 last year due to higher-than-expected sales of its own branded range launched in January and growth in its private label business. The company, acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November, serves markets in Europe, the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop attributes the production increase to a surge in orders from both domestic and international private label clients and its own brand, expressing optimism about the company's future success.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady with 20 years of service, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf, which failed to stop at a red light outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, admitted hitting Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, attributing the incident to being blinded by the setting sun. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse, acknowledging her love and importance to the children she served. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a NATO exercise focused on anti-submarine warfare in response to the growing threat from Russian submarines, which have increased their patrols in various waters, including near the UK. The exercise, named "Dynamic Mongoose," involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat, U33, commanded by Kai Nicklesdorf. The U-boat's mission is to simulate an attack on the USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights the difficulty of locating submarines underwater and the technological advancements of Russian submarines, which are described as the "quietest and most challenging adversary in the world."

For the first time, NATO has deployed underwater drones to assist in tracking the ocean floor, offering advantages such as lower cost, reduced risk to personnel, and persistent surveillance. Maritime patrol aircraft, like the French Atlantique, play a crucial role in anti-submarine warfare, though Britain lacks its own, making it reliant on allies for such capabilities. This absence is identified as a significant vulnerability, potentially allowing Russian submarines to monitor the UK's nuclear deterrent. The exercise serves as a reminder of NATO's collective strength and the need for nations, including Britain, to address their defense gaps, particularly in maritime patrol aircraft, to effectively counter the threat posed by advanced Russian submarines.

Since violence erupted in South Sudan in July, over 340,000 people have fled to neighboring Uganda, making it the largest refugee crisis this year. The conflict, rooted in ethnic tensions between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, has led to widespread killing, rape, and targeting of civilians. Uganda has been accommodating the influx, providing land and resources for refugees to establish shelters and begin farming. However, the sheer number of refugees is beginning to strain resources, particularly water supply. The international community is urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to end the violence.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old former footballer turned professional boxer since 2013, will face Jahmaine Smyle on 12 November at York Hall for the English super-middleweight championship. With a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights, McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage discusses the funding and construction of a new Bridgwater Community Hospital, part of a £330m coalition investment for new NHS facilities in England. The new hospital, costing £33m, will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and requires frequent maintenance. NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust will fund the remaining balance. The new hospital aims to improve patient well-being and is expected to be completed by autumn 2014, pending planning permission. This project is part of a broader initiative to modernize Somerset's healthcare facilities, with three out of 13 community hospitals already replaced in the past five years.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield's city centre. The victim, reportedly driving a black Mercedes, was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and later died at Northern General hospital. Local residents identified the man as a family member who was attending a celebration when the attack occurred. This incident follows several other shootings in Sheffield, including one in the Shiregreen area where a 25-year-old man was seriously injured, and another in Southey Green where an elderly couple was startled by shots fired through their window.

The passage discusses the activities of various hacker groups involved in the conflict in Ukraine, highlighting their methods and targets. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for DDoS attacks, hacking into Russian servers, and disrupting rebel websites. They also target electronic payment systems and public CCTV in rebel-held areas. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and has hacked Ukrainian government websites and electronic billboards. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, focuses on leaking documents from the Kremlin and has published material related to both Russia and Ukraine. These groups operate independently from government-sponsored entities and use various cyber warfare techniques to influence the conflict.

Several veteran Scottish Parliament members, including Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, former First Minister Alex Salmond, and Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, are stepping down ahead of the May 5 election. During their farewell speeches, both Salmond and McNeil emphasized the importance of the Scottish Parliament assuming greater responsibility for Scotland's governance. Salmond highlighted Scotland's diversity and the consensus on the need for the parliament to grow in power. McNeil warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster, particularly in terms of the committee system and ensuring accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie, a former Conservative MSP, also bid farewell, joking about her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She aims to gather experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing both positive and negative experiences to highlight good care and the impact of poor care. The review will assess various factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira's team will also consult with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment that the main advisory panel lacks representation from care home providers, which he believes is crucial for effective partnership and engagement.

The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported an £800,000 increase in pre-tax profit to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million. The company experienced growth in international sales across Europe and new markets. Harbro manufactures and supplies animal feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig, and poultry sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops in Scotland, offering products for farming and rural communities. The company noted the unpredictability of the agriculture outlook and the challenges faced over the past 12-18 months, while expressing confidence in their ability to handle future business challenges, including those potentially arising from Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden, Hertfordshire, on Saturday afternoon, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Detectives are treating the death as murder and urgently seek to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) in connection with the offense. McLoughlin is described as white, 6ft tall, with greying, collar-length hair, and of average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt. The police have warned the public not to approach him and have increased patrols in the area for resident reassurance.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, highlighted the weakening global economy in a speech, noting the IMF's latest assessment shows a delicate situation. This follows China's weaker-than-expected trade figures, with exports down by a quarter. The IMF may downgrade its 3.4% global growth forecast in April, impacting businesses reliant on China's growth.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the crossing at Cowes would be free until 2 July due to issues with the new vessel. The council ordered a review of the project by auditors, acknowledging a "frustrating and disappointing start" to the ferry, which has experienced breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Local businesses, like Valu-4-U, are concerned about the loss of trade, and compensation for damaged cars and businesses is under discussion. Transport councillor Ian Ward noted that the ferry is a prototype and expected teething problems, with electrical issues already rectified and ramp extensions authorized to prevent vehicle damage.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, an international temp agency based in London, has faced criticism for its job advertisements that specify physical attributes for potential hires, such as "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" for a personal assistant. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has condemned these ads as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women," and plans to contact the agency to address their hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners have also criticized the ads, with Sam Smethers of the Fawcett Society stating that the approach likely violates equality legislation. Despite the backlash, the agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, maintains that looks are important for their clients. Another ad for a "sexy female driver" has also been deemed "clearly unlawful" by employment lawyer James Lynas. The 2010 Equality Act prohibits discrimination based on various attributes, including age, sexual orientation, and disability, among others. Jansen has defended the ads by stating that clients, such as an older gentleman with a specific outfit in mind, have particular preferences. Matching Models counts MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team, and Harrods among its clients.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where an office assistant named Mahesh allegedly shot two students. Mahesh shot 18-year-old Gautami in the head, resulting in her death, and another student, Sirisha, who was severely injured but is expected to recover. Mahesh was arrested following a manhunt and has been remanded until April 12. Gun crime incidents in Indian educational institutions are rare. This incident echoes a 2007 event where a 14-year-old schoolboy was killed by fellow students near Delhi.

The advocacy group Glaad analyzed shows from June 2016 to May 2017, identifying 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16, but Glaad noted over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report highlighted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's study was based on scripted series already shown or with confirmed casting. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged progress but emphasized that numbers alone do not tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will not seek re-election amid controversy over a £10.25 million loan from the borough council to Northampton Town FC, which has gone missing and is under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. The loan, made when Mackintosh was the council leader, was intended to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, but the football stand remains half-built. A majority of his party's local executive council indicated they would vote to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old former police officer, fired a rifle into a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, Dallas, in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. He was subsequently charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault. The incident occurred while police were responding to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Despite initial claims that the car reversed towards him, footage showed it was moving away. Oliver was dismissed from the police force for policy violations and faces five to 99 years in prison if convicted. No trial date has been set, and he is currently free on bail. If convicted, he would be the first police officer in Dallas County to be convicted of murder since 1973.

The president-elect plans for Mrs. Trump and Barron to move to Washington after the school year ends, which has sparked criticism and speculation on social media. Historically, only two First Ladies did not reside in the White House during their husbands' terms: Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. Mrs. Trump's decision to delay the move is supported by some who believe it's a responsible choice for Barron's education. Historically, some First Ladies have not lived in the White House full-time or have taken on active public roles, such as Lou Henry Hoover and Eleanor Roosevelt. The role of the First Lady is ceremonial but can also involve supporting causes and providing a personal side to the White House. Melania Trump has expressed interest in tackling cyber-bullying. The White House can adapt to the family's needs, as seen with the Clintons and Obamas, who balanced their children's privacy with their public duties.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, is investigating the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and awaiting its findings. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) has instructed Pirc to undertake this investigation, and a report will be submitted to the COPFS.

The passage reports a yellow wind warning with potential gusts up to 75mph (120kmph), particularly affecting areas west of the mountains and moving in an unusual easterly direction. This could lead to travel disruptions on roads and at sea. The warning covers the counties of Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts already caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a major route into the town, with the road expected to remain closed for cleanup on Monday.

The Giants and Panthers played a closely contested game, with the Giants initially leading through Derrick Walser but the Panthers equalizing through Jeff Dimmen. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal, and Andy Bohmback equalized again. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored to give the Giants a 4-2 lead, but Nottingham's David Ling scored to narrow the gap. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25. The teams will meet again on Saturday night.

Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back due to a broken front wing on lap one and making five pit stops, finished fourth in the Chinese Grand Prix. Despite his efforts, he faces a 36-point deficit to Nico Rosberg with 18 races remaining. Sebastian Vettel came second for Ferrari, despite a first-lap collision with Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to fifth. The race was marked by multiple first-lap collisions and the introduction of the safety car. Hamilton's car was significantly damaged in an incident with Felipe Nasr, affecting his performance. Rosberg led from pole to victory, while Red Bull's Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo also secured podium positions. Hamilton remains confident in his ability to close the gap to Rosberg, though historically, no driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to win the World Championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to advance discussion on a topic often ignored in German football. His announcement was widely praised by former teammates, including Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, and supported by leading figures in German football administration such as Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball. Hitzlsperger's decision is seen as a significant step against homophobia in football, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck also expressing their support. This announcement is considered a watershed moment in Germany, which, like England, has struggled with homophobia in football. Hitzlsperger's courage is hoped to encourage others to break the taboo surrounding sexuality in the sport.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played 32 Championship games this season, helping Brighton achieve promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. His contract is set to expire, and he hopes to sign a new deal, expressing confidence in the team's ability to stay in the Premier League. Brighton secured promotion with a win over Wigan and leads second-placed Newcastle by four points. Sidwell previously played for several Premier League clubs and believes he deserves another chance at the top level. He signed a one-year deal with Brighton in June 2016 after a loan spell and has exceeded expectations in his performances.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool's Jamille Matt scored the opening goal in the 12th minute, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized through Kurtis Guthrie in the 17th minute. Blackpool's Sam Slocombe made crucial saves to keep the score level. Despite several chances, neither team could score again, and the match finished with a 1-1 scoreline. Colchester played the final moments with 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

A 29-year-old footballer, who previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season during their relegation from League One. He might debut for Colchester in the EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington on Saturday. For the latest football transfers, visit the dedicated page.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer in an attack outside the Houses of Parliament in March has led to a renewed focus on the need for a permanent memorial to honor police officers and staff who have died in the line of duty. The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising £1.5 million for a memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff. The memorial, to be completed by 2019, will include a brass screen with leaf shapes given to families of fallen officers as personal memorials. The government has committed £1 million towards the £4 million needed for the project.

Manchester United remains 15 points ahead at the top of the table with eight games left, following a 1-0 victory against Sunderland. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on upcoming games rather than past achievements, noting their record of 25 wins in the first 30 matches. The next significant game is the derby against Manchester City, where United holds a 15-point lead. Despite injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea, Ferguson plans to make changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea. He also mentioned the potential return of Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley, while confirming the availability of Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez. Ferguson praised the team's performance against Sunderland, highlighting their strong first half and resilient defense.

Mr. Schmidt stated that Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011 and emphasized that the company complies with what is legally required. He suggested that if the UK government wishes for companies to pay more taxes, it should change the tax system. Margaret Hodge proposed establishing a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms. Google, which routes most of its UK sales through Ireland, has been criticized for minimizing its UK tax payments. European Union leaders have agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Mr. Schmidt argued for corporate taxes to be levied where economic activity and risks are conducted, and called for a debate on international tax reform.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce the £3.6bn annual agency staff expenditure by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m by limiting agency staff pay to 55% above normal shift rates, excluding senior managers. Despite promising progress, NHS trusts are 10% short of their target, and it remains unclear if other pay bill spending has increased. NHS Improvement plans to publish league tables and collect data on the highest-earning agency staff to further monitor and control spending. Examples of excessive agency fees have been found, highlighting the need for continued efforts to reduce costs.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a hub of commerce, now symbolizes the economic downturn in the Republic of Ireland following the Celtic Tiger era. Despite the challenging times, local traders like Matt O'Brien, who runs a men's clothing shop, observe a gradual improvement in business. Fianna Fáil criticizes the Fine Gael-Labour coalition for its handling of the midlands, particularly regarding a half-a-billion euro investment in water meters instead of broadband. The government counters with the upcoming Center Parcs development, expected to create 1,000 jobs, though it requires planning permission. Local TD James Bannon highlights the region's natural attractions to draw tourists. However, traders suggest further actions, such as free street parking, could enhance local business. Overall, the midlands is experiencing early signs of economic recovery but requires additional efforts to fully revitalize.

The competition concludes on 29 May with the final match at the same stadium. Eight teams compete, playing each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. Key statistics include leading run-scorers Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249), with Warner and De Villiers sharing the most sixes (12 each) and Kohli having 8. The highest individual score is De Kock's 108, with Warner and Gambhir both scoring 90*. McClenaghan leads in wickets with 9, followed by Kumar (8) and Rahman (7). Four current or former England players participate: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants). The tournament schedule includes matches from 25 April to 29 May, with specific times and dates provided. The play-offs consist of Qualifier 1 on 24 May, Eliminator on 25 May, Qualifier 2 on 27 May, and the final on 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, highlighting a significant environmental issue due to their non-recyclability and improper disposal. Starting from October, England will implement a 5p charge per plastic bag to encourage reuse, following the example of Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where similar charges have led to a decrease in bag usage. Campaigners hope this measure will reduce waste and benefit the environment.

A severe wind event in Wales caused a school roof to be ripped off in Rhosgadfan, power cuts for hundreds of homes, train delays, and speed restrictions on major bridges. The high winds followed a yellow 'be aware' warning for wind across Wales. The highest gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey, leading to the cancellation of six Irish Ferries sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. Arriva Trains Wales warned of speed restrictions and delays on its services. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to the high winds. The winds eased by Friday evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in Denbighshire.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about a new project, aiming to put a different spin on it, though the specific role was not detailed. He will reunite with director Ryan Coogler, with whom he previously worked on "Creed." Jordan looks forward to collaborating again with Coogler and working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Nyong'o won an Oscar for her role in "12 Years a Slave," and Boseman is known for playing Black Panther in "Captain America: Civil War." Jordan recently portrayed the Human Torch in the "Fantastic Four" reboot, while Nyong'o played Maz Kanata in "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." The film "Black Panther" is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The theatre at Alexandra Palace, founded in 1875, is planned to be restored for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music, with a hoped reopening in 2018. The BBC studios at the Palace's eastern end will also be refurbished. These restorations are part of a larger project to transform Alexandra Palace into a cultural destination, with the glazed east court becoming a public and exhibition space. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8m and Haringey Council £6.8m, with the total cost for the east wing refurbishment being £26.6m. The Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the remaining £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, unused for decades, retains much of its original decor and stage machinery, originally designed for opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, earned 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, with minimal playing time at Euro 2016. Milner, who holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, scored his sole international goal during England's 5-0 win over Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. He expressed a wish for future success to his former manager, players, staff, and supporters.

Marcy Smith and her family's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by a fire that started from rubbish burned in the wood stove. Their son David, who was awake and on FaceTime with his father, alerted the family and ensured their escape. Unfortunately, their pets did not survive. The community has supported the family by donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Marcy praised David for his quick actions that likely saved their lives.

In 2010, Sullivan and Gold acquired a majority stake in West Ham for £105m, now owning over 85% of the club. There have been reports of a £200m offer from an energy drinks giant and interest from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority share to clear debts but emphasized their intention for ownership to pass to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards featured fan-voted categories such as best kiss and best shirtless performance, with Zac Efron winning the latter again. The Fault in Our Stars was the night's big winner, taking home best movie, best female performance (Shailene Woodley), the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss (Woodley and Ansel Elgort). Woodley dedicated her win to the book's author, John Green. Other notable winners included Bradley Cooper for American Sniper, Channing Tatum for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep for Into the Woods. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award, dedicating it to his children. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, presented by his Avengers co-stars. The ceremony also showcased upcoming films like the Pitch Perfect sequel, Trainwreck, and Avengers: Age of Ultron.

In July, Dundee United loaned 21-year-old Cammy Smith to St Mirren. Smith, a Scotland Under-21 international, has scored five goals this season and made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, where he scored four times in 89 appearances. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, praised the acquisition, highlighting Smith's maturity and potential to strengthen the attacking options. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that the warm weather has enabled its Jetpatcher machines to address potholes, aiming to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and to clear debris from gutters.

In December, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM). Rigging supervisor Steve Innes claimed they were not provided with proper personal protective equipment (PPE) and expressed concerns about potential long-term health effects, including cancer. EnQuest confirmed the exposure, stating that it was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) and that additional precautionary measures had been implemented. Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety and supported a joint investigation with EnQuest. The Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers, highlighting the importance of transparency in safety incidents. The HSE was aware of the incident but did not conduct an investigation as it was not reportable under RIDDOR.

The Asian Civilisations Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer's manager later confessed to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including this sculpture, which is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The allegations surfaced during a 2012 court case against the firm for trafficking antiquities. Following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), ACM decided to return the sculpture after the ASI officially requested its return in May. Although there is no conclusive proof that the sculpture was stolen from the specified temple, ACM considered the dealer's confession. The museum plans to take legal action to seek compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with tremors felt as far as Milan and Florence. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but phone lines and power supplies were disrupted in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy, which is prone to earthquakes, is still recovering from the 2009 L'Aquila earthquake that killed almost 300 people. In 2012, seven individuals were convicted for providing misleading information prior to the L'Aquila disaster.

On 8 September 2016, Austin Grant from Sheffield, who was skeptical about South Yorkshire's climate for fruit growth, expressed excitement as he observed some results. The fruit, still attached to the plant, is not ripe enough to eat yet. The 62-year-old grandfather was "literally jumping for joy."

Rockstar has delayed the release of their game until 24 March, originally scheduled for 27 January, to allow for additional testing and polishing. The company assured fans that the extra time will improve the game. Online heists for consoles will be released before the PC version. Screenshots from the PC version show enhanced detail, with 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor setups. Minimum PC specifications for the game have been released. Grand Theft Auto V previously became the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in revenue in three days.

The 76-year-old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. This painting, depicting a leper squint from medieval churches, was described as "quite extraordinary" by judge Ansel Krut, despite being "difficult to look at." Simpson, who has been shortlisted and longlisted for the prize multiple times, expressed his delight at finally winning. The prize money will be used for art supplies, including canvas, stretches, and high-quality paints. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with notable past winners such as David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, experienced night-time attacks by four masked assailants, resulting in shattered windows and fires that were quickly extinguished by firefighters. No casualties were reported, and police have cordoned off the areas. The attacks occurred almost simultaneously, with no group claiming responsibility. This follows a previous incident in September where pro-government protesters attacked the offices of the daily Hurriyet.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. The former Burton player will officially join on January 1, marking Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsene Wenger, Arsenal's manager, has commented on Gareth Southgate's interim role with the England national team, stating that Southgate has accumulated experiences and is a good observer. Wenger believes Southgate has a good opportunity to show his competency and quality. Wenger also mentioned his focus on his job and did not comment extensively on his own links to the England role. Additionally, Wenger discussed Arsenal players, including offering a new contract to defender Hector Bellerin and noting that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss a couple more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint investigation with the Health and Safety Executive, and Fruehauf is fully cooperating with the inquiry.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats, Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck under contract with Serco Northlink. The RMT union had reported that some crew members were earning less than £4 an hour. The charter change will revert contracted services to Serco Northlink starting next month. Seatruck had argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to address the pay gap but Seatruck refused. The new arrangements, pending finalization of financial and regulatory details, will ensure all crew members receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink holds a six-year, £243m contract for operating three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles, a route heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and, along with his mother, admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

A team led by Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, along with researchers from other universities, discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. These ditched enclosures, termed "geoglyphs," were concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest until modern deforestation revealed them. The function of these sites remains unclear, though they are unlikely to be villages or defensive structures due to the lack of artifacts and their layout. They might have been used sporadically as ritual gathering places. Soil analysis suggests these geoglyphs were built among taller vegetation, unlike other ritual sites, and were likely not visible above the forest canopy. The research challenges the assumption that Amazonian forests were pristine before European arrival, indicating human influence over 6,000 years ago through the artificial spread of plant species and selective cultivation of economically valuable trees, akin to "prehistoric supermarket" practices. There is evidence suggesting that some of Acre's remaining forests may still reflect these ancient agroforestry practices.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes at the Shanghai Masters. This win follows his recent Japan Open victory on Sunday, bringing him closer to the top 10 rankings. Kyrgios attributed his subdued performance to fatigue and lack of sleep due to the demanding travel and schedule, contrasting with his previous outburst at the same tournament last year.

Scientists, charities, and medical professionals advocate for the HPV vaccine to be extended to boys in Wales to protect against head and neck cancers, citing an increase in such cases among younger men. Currently, the vaccine is administered to girls aged 12 and 13 to prevent cervical cancer. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any decisions. In 2008, an HPV vaccination program was initiated in schools, achieving an 85% vaccination rate among girls in Wales.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, documented his cancer journey on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey, which garnered over 28,000 Likes. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude and was celebrated at a school prom held in his honor, where he briefly attended before leaving due to feeling unwell. His mother, Allison, announced his passing on his Facebook page. Throughout his treatment, Jak was visited by various celebrities and sports figures, and his story inspired many. A special football match was planned to raise further funds for charity in his memory.

In a closely contested match, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda, thanks to a late goal by Abdallah El Said in the 89th minute, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the match. The win places Egypt in a position to play Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament. Ghana had already secured their place in the quarter-finals with a 1-0 win over Mali.

Lancashire County Council plans to develop a new railway station in Skelmersdale, utilizing land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus. This decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail. The proposed station aims to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. County councillor John Fillis highlighted the site's potential for future expansion and its good connectivity. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station.
During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28-year-old woman was found seriously injured on a pavement, having been dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. The woman's 38-year-old ex-partner, from nearby Bad Muender, later turned himself in to authorities. Both the victim and the suspect are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are less likely to receive one. The research, based on data from 4,600 workers in Australia, debunked the "reticent female" theory, showing no evidence that women avoid asking for more money. When comparing full-time male and female workers, men were 25% more likely to receive a pay rise after asking. The study also found no support for the idea that women are reluctant to ask for raises due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from stereotypes. The researchers accounted for various factors, including employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications. The findings suggest some element of discrimination against women, with younger women showing more successful negotiation behaviors.

Oxford City Council has been using funds for ground investigations to find a new burial site but has not found a suitable location. The two remaining cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council continues to explore options despite having run out of suitable land within Oxford. After the remaining cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, use of reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information, videos, and band interviews via their phones and tablets by interacting with signs and posters on site. Notable acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The app aims to enhance the festival experience for visitors and enable global interaction with the event.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. Despite past symptoms of post-race ataxia, he showed no such symptoms during the race. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed there were no significant underlying health issues. The incident is rare and can occur in horses without prior health problems. The sport is committed to understanding and preventing such occurrences.

In 2004, Davina, then known as David Ayrton, met a 15-year-old girl in a Portsmouth garage and raped her while two others slept. Davina, now 34, denied the charge and will be sentenced on March 4. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, likely at a male prison in Winchester, due to concerns she might be a risk to herself or fail to attend court. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer and protocols have been established for her detention. Ayrton, who changed her name in 2012 and has not made physical changes or taken medication related to her gender identity, spoke about her sexuality during the trial. The victim clearly recollected the attack, having only consumed a can and a half of Foster's. Ayrton disclosed the attack to a care home worker in 2014.

In Rio, the Serbian doubles team lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares with a score of 6-4, 6-4. This followed a singles defeat for Novak Djokovic by Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the world number one, had previously suffered a surprising third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July against American Sam Querrey. Despite these setbacks, Djokovic later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US will participate in Saturday's event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, using only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, has been recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in September. He is nearing a return to play and aims to be fit for the Six Nations in February. Webb has renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, prioritizing his position to play for his country. Wales' Six Nations campaign starts away to Ireland on February 7.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents encountered two men near the US-Canada border, leading to the arrest of two individuals for attempting to smuggle 58lb (26kg) of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. One man, Nathan Hall, fled and was later arrested in Canada. Jeffrey Laviolette was taken into custody immediately. Two others, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their roles in the drug transportation plan. The suspects face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is known for drug and firearm smuggling.

The NSPCC's Childline reported a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, rising from about 2,400 in 2011-12 to over 4,500 in the past year. The actual number of children suffering from online abuse is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have shared experiences of torment, abuse, and fear of attending school due to online trolls. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized the severity of cyber-bullying and urged adults, parents, and teachers to intervene to protect children. The report was released at the beginning of Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with various organizations to address the issue. A young person who contacted Childline described how online harassment affected their mental health, highlighting the need for understanding and support from parents and schools. Advice from young people on dealing with bullying was also included.

Following a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which Israel rejected, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office requested the postponement of a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in West Bank settlements. This decision aimed to avoid further straining relations with Washington ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The settlements, considered illegal under international law, are a major obstacle to achieving a two-state solution and peace. The resolution condemned building in East Jerusalem, which Israel claims as its capital, while Palestinians want it as the capital of their future state.

On the eve of Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, various events and tributes were held to honor her. Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch, highlighting her duty, service, tolerance, and commitment. A picture of the Queen with Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George was released for stamps to mark the occasion. The Queen visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, met staff, and viewed an exhibition, marking the 500th anniversary of the postal service. She also attended a ceremony in Alexandra Gardens to open a new bandstand and met pupils from local schools. Political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, expressed their anticipation to wish the Queen a happy birthday. Ten stamps were released to celebrate the Queen's birthday, featuring four generations of the Royal Family. On her actual birthday, the Queen and Prince Philip unveiled a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway in Windsor and lit a beacon to start a series of more than 900 beacons across the UK and around the world. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama joined the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle. The Queen celebrates two birthdays each year, her actual birthday on 21 April and her official birthday on a Saturday in June. Some critics, like the Republic pressure group, argued that the Queen's birthday did not warrant such extensive coverage and that the BBC had a "duty to report, not to celebrate the royals."

West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory over League Two side Cheltenham Town in the EFL Cup second round. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored in the first half, with Sakho's goal being his first since November. Cheltenham had some chances but failed to test West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian significantly. The match ended with West Ham advancing to the next round, marking the end of League Two's representation in the competition before the third-round draw.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion caused by Andreas Werner, 46, who failed to see the motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court. He was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not believe jail time would be beneficial, accepting it was a momentary lapse. Werner, who was staying near Bala with his family, expressed remorse with no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, west London, attempted to return to the UK after fighting in Syria. He was a prominent member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, and was involved in producing propaganda and soliciting donations. Khawaja was considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists due to his active role in Syria's conflict and his efforts to conceal his return to the UK, including faking his own death online. He faces up to life imprisonment for his activities and has admitted to four offenses, with a more serious charge of soliciting to murder lying on file.

Jackson, a 22-year-old player, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, who finished eighth in the table. Barnsley has signed Jackson as their third signing for next season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Caretaker boss Paul Heckingbottom praised Jackson's pace and ability to challenge defenders, noting he will fit well into the team's style of play. Jackson rejected a contract offer from Wrexham for the upcoming season. For the latest football transfers, visit the dedicated page.

A large number of sealed bottles, believed to be Vanish detergent, have washed up on Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves in Cornwall, posing a risk to wildlife. The National Trust and volunteers are clearing the bottles, though some have leaked. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency stated that while a container from the MV Blue Ocean was lost during stormy weather, there is no concrete evidence linking it to the washed-up bottles. Cornwall Wildlife Trust expressed concern about the impact on marine life. The public has been advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not to attempt to recover them. Cornwall Council, along with partners, is monitoring the situation.

An incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00, resulting in minor injuries to several people. The road was closed, and diversions were established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is conducting ongoing inquiries into the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French center-back, made 14 appearances last season, helping Bolton Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in total. Manager Phil Parkinson noted that Dervite made a significant contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite has now signed a new contract with Bolton, following the promotions of David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The passage discusses tensions between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour in the House of Lords, particularly regarding Brexit. Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything," while Labour's Baroness Smith claimed the Lib Dems were offering "false hope." The two parties had previously collaborated to defeat the government on issues like the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, this cooperation ended when MPs rejected these amendments, with the Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems for "fairly obvious grandstanding" aimed at campaign content, while Lib Dem Baroness Ludford accused Labour of supporting the government's plans and a "hard Brexit." Despite past alliances on various issues, the Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and doubted future collaboration.

In the current election, defense is a low priority for most political parties, with public concern ranking it behind the economy, NHS, and immigration. UK military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya have contributed to public fatigue and political reticence on the subject. Despite global instability, the UK has been reducing its armed forces, with the regular Army size being cut from 102,000 to 82,000. The UK has fallen to sixth place in global defense spending and is likely to fall below the NATO threshold of 2% GDP spending on defense. The Conservatives plan to replace Trident and increase the defense equipment budget by 1% annually, while Labour and the Liberal Democrats have not made similar commitments. The future of the UK's nuclear deterrent is uncertain, with no political consensus on the issue. The Royal Navy faces challenges in crewing its new aircraft carriers and has scaled down plans for equipping them with new jets.

Barcelona, the Spanish champions, have denied any wrongdoing in relation to the signing of Neymar from Santos, despite allegations that the actual cost of the player was significantly higher than initially reported. The club paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. Including signing-on fees, wages, agents' fees, and a recent tax payment, the total cost to the club is £106.8m. Barcelona made an additional tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover potential divergent interpretations of their tax responsibility. The club maintains that the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. The case remains under investigation, and it is not yet confirmed whether it will be dropped following Barcelona's payment. Neymar has scored ten goals in 25 appearances for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father from Nottingham, tragically died in a motorway crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way in a Mazda Premacy. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for retired individuals, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of older people maintaining their driving abilities for independence. Currently, UK drivers over 70 must complete a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licenses, but no medical or driving tests are required. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) states that there is no evidence suggesting older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents than others.

The passage discusses concerns over the safety of transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, with many women experiencing debilitating side effects. Two patients on the original review group resigned in protest over the perceived watered-down report. Alison Britton, a professor of healthcare and medical law, will examine the review process and report on lessons for the future. The report concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended a range of treatments and mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the health secretary confirmed the recommendations would be implemented. Tracey Gillies, the chairwoman of the independent review, apologized for not uniting all panel members around the final report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh implants, with more than 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old indoor 3-mile record by 14 seconds, achieving a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan initially raised concerns about whether the race met UK Athletics' criteria for record attempts, specifically questioning if it was a "genuine race" and if drug testing was conducted. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time is expected to be ratified as official. McColgan praised Muir's potential to win world medals and noted that Muir still has room for improvement in her 5K time. McColgan also highlighted the similarity between Muir's race and her own record-breaking race 25 years ago, expressing satisfaction that a fellow Scot broke her record.

Jung won the event aboard Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou who had an infection. Astier Nicolas of France took silver, and Phillip Dutton from the USA won bronze, while GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th. Fox-Pitt, who had been in an induced coma after a fall just 10 months prior, performed well in the final show-jumping phase but had a poor cross-country phase that dropped him to 21st. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. Additionally, the passage mentions an invitation to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse at Official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics and provides a guide to getting into equestrian sports.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old Briton, won a four-set match against 29th seed Fabio Fognini, with a final score of 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5, after two hours and 39 minutes. Murray saved five set points to avoid a fifth set and will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the last 16 for the 11th time. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week of the tournament with a win over Maria Sakkari. Murray described the match as tense and up and down, expressing relief to finish before the lights dimmed.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven. Police found several people still at the bar and till receipts indicated alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the 43-year-old license holder from Kevin Lynch Park, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, while James Thomas, 44, from the same address, faced one count of the same charge. The defense acknowledged that licensing laws were not strictly followed and the bar was not run properly. The judge criticized O'Neill's "appalling record" and expressed concern over the inability to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, launching the Ulster Unionist Party's manifesto, emphasized the importance of partnership over domination and expressed a preference for forming a government with the SDLP rather than Sinn Féin. He stood by his remarks despite controversy, particularly regarding vote transfer to the SDLP. Nesbitt denied any regrets and highlighted the party's focus on issues like tackling waiting lists, increasing police numbers, and addressing Brexit impacts. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', also includes a section on 'Cleaning Up Stormont', addressing themes of incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has confirmed that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aiming to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales by implementing automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. This initiative, known as 'Turing's Law' after Alan Turing, will provide posthumous pardons and allow living men convicted of such offences to apply for a pardon. The motion is expected to include the same provisions and will be considered by the assembly to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race with a time of 4 minutes, 19.12 seconds, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This achievement surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and placed Muir second on the British all-time list behind Zola Budd's time of 4:17.57. Muir, who also holds the Scottish mile record and finished fifth in last year's World Championships, expressed her excitement about her performance and hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from 24 to 26 June. She started her season with an 800m victory in France and will next compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm. Muir balances her training with her veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year of vet school.
The passage mentions that there are pictures from 26 beaches in Scotland, which have been ranked as the "most excellent" for water quality.

In the passage, Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC asserts that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi likely had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko, but the Russian state is likely to have been the sponsor of the plot. UK officials believe the two suspects poisoned Litvinenko in London in 2006 with a fatal dose of radioactive substance polonium-210, though they deny any wrongdoing. Horwell emphasizes that while the Russian state was likely involved, it does not necessarily mean President Vladimir Putin was involved or gave the order. Litvinenko, who defected to the UK in 2000, had accused the FSB of various crimes, which could have been seen as treachery. The passage also mentions the unknown risks to the general public in London from polonium radiation and the fact that Litvinenko had been poisoned twice before his death. The suspects left a trail of polonium and have no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them. Although the force wanted them tried for murder, extradition attempts have failed, and they remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed as the new captain of the Australian cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke who retired after the Ashes defeat. Smith will also captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Smith has previously captained the team in three Tests against India and has played in 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, has matured and is seen as an important senior figure in the team. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the upcoming limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron, the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, expressed his passion for LGBT-plus rights and emphasized that defending equal marriage would be a top priority for him. He refused to directly answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, instead stating that he believes everyone is a sinner. Farron also highlighted the need to extend marital rights to transgender people, addressing the issue of the spousal veto. Although he voted against the Equality Bill in 2007, he clarified that he is a liberal and supports equality, and his concerns were related to the protection of individual liberties.

In 2015, Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare plans to repurpose the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to rehire many former Sanofi employees. A spokesman for Accord expressed confidence in the investment's "extremely positive" impact on the area. Councillor Nick Forbes of Newcastle City Council praised the announcement, highlighting its benefits for the local economy and the region's reputation in the science and healthcare sectors. Accord Healthcare is a global pharmaceutical company that develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 products to approximately 60 countries.
