The local authority announced that Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, will leave at the end of his contract on Friday. Additionally, Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, attributes these departures to the council's inability to retain senior staff and anticipates more resignations. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider experienced a crash at this year's TT, and the Fireblade bike faced mechanical issues. Initially, Martin announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he is not quitting road racing entirely, just Hondas for the rest of the year. He did not participate in the North West 200 after his teammate's crash and will also skip the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a disaster and mentioned that the bike won't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading to his withdrawal from the event. He expressed interest in racing classics and other non-traditional events in the future.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which lost the presidential election last month for the first time, also lost control of key northern states and was defeated in areas affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, it retained Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC's Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May. The APC made historic gains, relegating the PDP to a regional party, but failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could disrupt oil production and impact federal revenue. The elections were more peaceful than previous years, though violence occurred in some areas due to ethnic differences and rivalry. The PDP, in power for 16 years, faces introspection and rebuilding under a new leader due to voter demand for change, defections, and allegations of corruption.

A US-based environmental lobby group, Mighty, has accused Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to the haze caused by slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, denies the allegations and claims to have a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy. Mighty's report also claims that Olam has created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" and that Temasek's investment in Olam means that Singapore's state fund may have unwittingly financed unsustainably produced palm oil. The palm oil industry globally has a troubled track record, often accused of unfair and illegal labor practices, deforestation, and burning of plantations. Olam has also been accused of bulldozing rainforests to establish monoculture palm oil plantations in Gabon, which it denies, claiming its partnerships in the country are responsible and transparent.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started serving puppy platters following a new law permitting dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they were outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri's knee injury makes him a doubt for the upcoming game, having only played from the bench in the last two matches. David Nugent, Derby County's striker with a groin injury, might return after missing the recent draw with Huddersfield. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is aiming for a starting position after scoring a late equalizer off the bench against the Terriers.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator has lifted the ban on YouTube, stating it is no longer necessary as Google has launched a Pakistan-specific version. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) confirmed that internet service providers have been directed to restore access to YouTube. While many young Pakistanis welcome the lifting of the ban, some activists demand transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the government. The ministry of information technology stated that Google has provided a process for the PTA to request the blocking of offending material, which YouTube may restrict access to after review. YouTube has denied that government requests for content removal will be automatically granted, emphasizing adherence to community guidelines and thorough review processes. The initial ban was imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 following the controversial US-made film "Innocence of Muslims."

Domenico Scala, who heads FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian and excused himself from the 2015 elections due to a shared nationality with a candidate, Sepp Blatter. Musa Bility, the LFA boss, threatens to go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations. Scala's spokesman, Andreas Bantel, argues that nationality alone does not constitute a conflict of interest. The upcoming election to replace long-standing president Blatter involves five candidates and will occur in 18 days. Bility, who was denied participation in the elections, pledges his support to Prince Ali and urges fellow Africans to do the same. The election will be held in Zurich, Switzerland.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search has been conducted, and evidence suggests a flashover explosion caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations but avoided it by apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints made during the 2015 tournament. Morocco was allowed to participate in the 2017 Nations Cup after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) overturned a ban. Morocco had been banned and fined for refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to Ebola fears, but CAS later reduced the fine. Tunisia's dispute with Caf arose from a contentious penalty awarded in their 2015 quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea, which they believed was unjust. After discussions with Caf president Issa Hayatou, Tunisia resolved their differences and secured their place in the 2017 tournament. Both Tunisia and Morocco are optimistic about their future in African football.

Following a mass fracas in the 95th minute of a match at Etihad Stadium, where Chelsea won 3-1, Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, his second such dismissal this season, after a challenge on Chelsea's David Luiz. Fernandinho was banned for three matches due to his involvement in the ensuing scuffle with Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas, who faced no further action. Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's behavior. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

In Wales and other parts of the UK, there are some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. A pilot scheme in Cynon Valley and Neath is focusing on patients whose family doctors suspect have cancer but show no urgent signs or symptoms. This follows a visit by doctors to Denmark to see their diagnostic systems. Cwm Taf Health Board officials saw that the health service in Denmark had improved cancer survival rates. The concern is that a patient in Wales without clear symptoms waits too long for a diagnosis because they do not "fit easily" into any specific treatment pathway. This means family doctors refer the patient back and forth to get several tests, which takes several weeks. Therefore, the fear is that too many patients start treatment when their cancer has progressed or cannot be improved. Forty doctors in Cynon Valley who believe something might be wrong can refer the patient to a diagnostic center at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant within seven days. It is estimated that about six patients per week will be seen and given different tests, with the hope that this will happen on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with worrying symptoms are diagnosed in the Cwm Taf area. Doctors therefore want to reach most of the patients without such obvious symptoms sooner. A similar clinic will be established at Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another trial by Abertawe Bro Morgannwg Health Board. The trials have been developed over the past 12 months since experts from Wales returned from Aarhus. Denmark established diagnostic centers after concerns that the country was lagging behind in cancer survival rates. According to Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of the Wales Cancer Network Liaison, the scheme will reassure patients but also speed up the process. "If the family doctor sees a patient who is not sure what is wrong but is worried and feels something is wrong, it will give the family doctor the opportunity to refer the patient directly to the clinic and mean the patient will be seen quickly and hopefully diagnosed." Gareth Jordan, a family doctor in Aberdare, says the pilot scheme could make a big difference to patients' lives. "I would say, 'I've seen this man, he's lost a lot of weight... might not send him off for specialist tests or if we did, the tests would be given in order of likelihood'. But the fact that they are seen in one place and everyone sees rapid progress, the likelihood is an early diagnosis if they have cancer in my opinion." If the Cynon Valley pilot scheme - which will last six months -

England defeated Pakistan by a significant margin at Old Trafford, leveling the series. They scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, marking their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his impressive performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket. Alastair Cook praised Root's stepping up to number three and his controlled play. Pakistan struggled, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests. Despite the loss, Misbah expressed hope for his team's improvement. The series is expected to be tight, with Vaughan suggesting England should enjoy their win but remain focused.

Head coach Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with interim coach Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for the third time, having previously led Wales in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde, with discussions at an advanced stage. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team, providing a valuable opportunity for development and inspiration.

In a Premier League match, Hull City managed to secure their first league win since August 20, ending a six-game losing streak, despite remaining in the bottom three. Southampton, fresh off a Europa League victory, started strong with Charlie Austin's early penalty. However, Hull City's Robert Snodgrass, who came on as a substitute, scored within two minutes of entering the game, followed by Michael Dawson's header, turning the tide. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull City's David Marshall made crucial saves, and Sam Clucas cleared a corner off the goal line in added time. Hull City's win came amid injuries to key players and a disheartened fan base, but Snodgrass's performance lifted the team and fans alike.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor at around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa. The motorcyclist, who lived locally, was the only fatality, while the tractor driver was uninjured. Lincolnshire Police have not released further details about the motorcyclist and are appealing for witnesses. The B1191 road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, aiming to "put an end to the agony" before early elections in June. This decision was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, who argue it is illegal and threatens Macedonia's EU membership ambitions. The crisis began in 2015 with recordings allegedly showing ministers plotting vote-rigging and covering up a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing recordings since 2015, accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 people and revealing high-level corruption. The government denies these accusations and claims Zaev is trying to destabilize the nation.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager quickly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as their top choice. The club, which was promoted to the Premier League in 2011 and rose from near bankruptcy, fears it may struggle if relegated due to the strengthened Championship. Curtis, a former player, believes the team has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 and questions if new players are adequately replacing those who have left. Despite this, Curtis thinks the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League One after a loss to Leyton Orient, despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona. Armand Gnanduillet's winning goal for Orient kept their play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who reached the Football League in 2007, return to the National League under manager John Still. The team has struggled with a poor goal difference and attack, with Jamie Cureton scoring only nine goals this season. Still expressed his commitment to helping the Daggers gain promotion from the National League next season. Leyton Orient's victory leaves them two points from the play-off spots, and comes after the removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler emphasized the importance of professionalism and winning games to achieve their goals.

Steven Gerrard, the former Liverpool captain, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February, marking his first job since retiring as a player. Jurgen Klopp, the current Liverpool manager, expressed his approval of Gerrard's appointment, highlighting his potential to become a manager in the future. Gerrard, who made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and retired in November after a 19-year career, is also working towards his UEFA A coaching license.

McManus scored twice, including a close-range goal in the first quarter and a late goal, while Forbes and Johnstone also scored, leading to a comfortable win for the hosts. Alloa managed to pull one back through McAusland before half-time.

Ofsted discovered children being taught in squalid conditions in three closed illegal schools in Birmingham. Running such schools can result in up to 51 weeks in jail. The government is considering more regulation for places teaching over 6 to 8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed shock at the conditions and believes these cases are just the beginning. Eighteen unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been investigated. Any place teaching over 20 hours a week must register as a school. Some part-time education centers or "flexi schools" operate legally but may be exploiting the right to home educate. Sir Michael criticized officials for slow action and confusing advice. The government has funded a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, which will apply to all religious groups. The Education Secretary intends to prosecute unregistered schools and has asked Ofsted to prepare cases. A government consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is set to become the Scottish Borders' first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights the unique scale of their operation, housed in a small cowshed, and emphasizes their focus on capturing the local flavor of the Teviot valley. The distillery aims to use local botanicals, aligning with the ethos of local sourcing. Named after the legendary Borders figure Lilliard, the gin pays homage to the region's history and strong female production team. John Henderson of Born in the Borders expresses excitement about hosting the first new distillery in nearly 200 years and tasting the new gin.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died after Gary Green, 51, reversed his vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before the incident. He was prosecuted under health and safety legislation and sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her grief and emphasized the importance of not driving under the influence. The Health and Safety Executive described the incident as extremely tragic and Green's behavior as reckless.

Luis Suarez, a 27-year-old Uruguayan striker, can now train and play in friendly matches following a ruling by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS). CAS upheld FIFA's ban on Suarez from playing "organised" matches but deemed the complete prohibition on all football-related activities excessive. Consequently, Suarez can participate in training sessions, friendly matches, attend games, and engage in promotional activities. He will still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games, with his competitive debut for Barcelona likely against Real Madrid on October 26. Suarez's lawyers argued that FIFA's suspension for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup was too severe. CAS confirmed the sanctions but allowed Suarez to resume football activities, while FIFA and the world players' union Fifpro expressed disappointment with the ruling.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna from the UK won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene from Lithuania. The race involved a 380-metre course with obstacles like haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. Rich and Anna trained for a week and will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond reassured Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that job roles would change, rather than result in job losses, when the paper car tax disc system is replaced with an electronic one in October 2014. Hammond explained that while there may be a reduction in job opportunities due to fewer refunds and the withdrawal of tax discs, employees would be redeployed to other areas of the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA). This response aimed to alleviate concerns among the 5,000 DVLA workers and was welcomed by Hedges, who acknowledged the benefits of the new system despite the reduction in job opportunities.

Hungary's Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto stated that Hungary will not backtrack on its controversial laws regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, which have drawn objections from the EU. Szijjarto emphasized that these laws are a matter of national competence and should not be interfered with by European institutions. Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU has expressed concerns over Hungary's treatment of asylum seekers and the potential closure of the Central European University, founded by George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws. The EU has warned of potential action if there are no positive developments.

The passage provides information about the cast and release of the live-action adaptation of the film "Beauty and the Beast." Key points include: Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Kevin Kline as Maurice, Luke Evans and Josh Gad as Gaston and LeFou respectively, and Angela Lansbury's successor playing Mrs. Potts. The film, directed by Bill Condon, is set for release on March 17, 2017, with filming starting in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist for the Sunday Times, passed away after a battle with multiple cancers. Despite his illness, Gill remained positive and was described as "stoical." He was celebrated for his exceptional writing, wit, and fearless journalism. Gill's final column, reflecting on his diagnosis, was published posthumously. Colleagues and friends, including Sunday Times editor Martin Ivens, paid tribute to his unparalleled talent and compassionate nature. Gill's career was marked by both admiration and controversy due to his bold and often provocative writing style. He overcame dyslexia to become a successful writer and author, contributing significantly to the Sunday Times since 1993. Gill was engaged to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, at the time of his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was attacked in Ulan Bator while performing in a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol. Russian news reported that he was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating but claims local press reports are distorted. Sukhbaatar spent about 10 days in a coma due to serious brain injuries. The alleged attacker, a Russian official, has not been identified. Sukhbaatar's family and lawyer deny claims that he shouted "Heil Hitler" during the performance. The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, was not detained due to the injury not being serious, not because of diplomatic immunity. The case is under investigation by Mongolian police.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid staged a demonstration on Monday against the airport's expansion plans, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. They are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST, prompting the Metropolitan Police to announce a review of airport security.

Nick Selman scored a mature 101 for Glamorgan, his second first-class century, helping his team to a total dominated by his innings. However, seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took wickets regularly for Gloucestershire in cloudy conditions. Aneurin Donald contributed 36, while Taylor and Miles excelled with the ball. Glamorgan, led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, managed a consolation bonus point. Gloucestershire's innings focused on survival, ending the day evenly balanced. Selman expressed relief at scoring runs after a series of low scores, while Taylor highlighted the challenging conditions and praised the bowling performance.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after discussing a planned murder bid online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. He intended to make a false police report to ambush and shoot officers at the Dee Estuary. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. He had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. The Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counseling for those in difficulty.

Surrey posted a total of 255-7, with significant contributions from Davies and Ben Foakes, who shared a 130-run partnership. Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst, which included key dismissals of Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite Tim Bresnan's 68, Yorkshire fell short, being all out for 236. Surrey's Gareth Batty praised the team's collective effort and highlighted the crucial partnership between Davies and Foakes. Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment, noting the team's strong season but lack of performance in crucial moments.

A 56ft converted trawler, located 6 miles west of South Stack, experienced flooding when its pump failed. At 07:00 BST, the crew contacted Holyhead coastguards for assistance. The RNLI lifeboat crew intervened by providing a pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games in April due to her veterinary medicine exams in May. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, achieving a new outdoor personal best time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. Despite her disappointment at missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir is focused on completing her degree and sees potential for future events, including the World Indoor Championships in March.

Robbie Savage's BBC Sport column discusses Liverpool's challenges in repeating last season's title performance, focusing on their current form, lineup against Chelsea, and Steven Gerrard's future. Liverpool is far from last season's level, needing significant improvement to secure a top-four finish. Manager Brendan Rodgers faces criticism for his transfer strategy, particularly the lack of adequate replacements for Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge. Liverpool's attack has lost intensity, and their defense remains problematic despite investments. Despite these issues, Gerrard is seen as crucial to Liverpool's future, though his physical and mental resilience is tested by age and past failures. Chelsea is expected to dominate their upcoming match, highlighting Liverpool's current difficulties.

The £45m facility in Kilmarnock, East Ayrshire, will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The council plans to name the campus after renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney, known for his contributions to Tartan Noir and works like the Laidlaw trilogy, was passionate about education. He transitioned from being an English teacher to a full-time writer and became influential in various fields including poetry, journalism, and broadcasting. He passed away on December 5.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated and nearby residents advised to stay indoors due to a suspected British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s. The mine, spotted on Monday, led to the evacuation of three streets and safety advisories for residents within 500 meters. An exclusion zone was also established on the river and at sea, disrupting ferry services and boating activities. Authorities, including Ch Insp Elliot Brown and Lt Cdr Tim Castrinoyannakis, emphasized the precautionary nature of the evacuation and the uncertainty regarding the mine's explosive content. Inverclyde Council thanked the community for their cooperation during the operation.

The passage discusses the funding decisions made by UK Sport for Team GB's preparation for the Tokyo 2020 Olympics and Paralympics. Key points include:

- A total of £345 million will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, £2 million less than the Rio Games.
- Funding for cycling has been cut by over £4 million to £25.98 million.
- Badminton is the only sport that earned a medal in Rio to have its funding removed, despite achieving a bronze medal.
- UK Sport has set a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo.
- Judo, which also earned a bronze medal in Rio, has had its funding slightly increased.
- The decision to cut funding was made to prioritize and enhance medal potential, with the aim of maintaining the historic success seen at Rio 2016.
- Investment in five new Olympic sports and two new Paralympic sports for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed, with £9 million of the total £345 million budget still to be allocated.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff, a designated conservation area, will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage objected to the scale of the development, but councillors voted seven to three in favor, citing benefits to tourism. The new development will include a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments. The council received 246 letters in support of the plans, while 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, emphasizing the historic character of the area.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely while off-duty in Brecon. Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon," punched and beat Boyd outside a bar called The Cellar, dragging his unconscious body away before fleeing. Boyd's body was found by police on 8 May. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of any involvement in the attack as he had left the scene before the violence began. The community of Brecon was shocked by the attack, and Boyd's family described him as a loving, caring, and loyal person with a promising career ahead of him.

Andrew Travers, the former chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement following a significant error during an election where voters were initially turned away from all polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched to examine the incident. Travers expressed confidence in the borough's future growth and transformation. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes to affected residents. Travers attributed the issues to electoral registration lists. The investigation will conclude by the end of May and will review the appropriateness of arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum.

In a closely contested match, Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored first for Gateshead with a free-kick, but Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham with a set-piece before halftime. Ryan Bowman secured the win for Gateshead with a header in the second half. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's performance in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's inability to capitalize on their chances.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan and Mozambique are at the bottom.

OneWeb, in partnership with Airbus, plans to create a satellite network of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, aiming to provide global broadband connectivity, especially to schools. This ambitious project necessitates a significant shift in satellite manufacturing towards high-volume, low-cost production, using assembly line methods similar to automotive and aerospace industries. Airbus has introduced new assembly lines in Toulouse, France, and Florida, USA, featuring automated trolley robots to streamline satellite production. The project requires a large-scale rocket campaign, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles scheduled to launch clusters of satellites into a 1,200km orbit. OneWeb aims to have nearly 300 satellites operational by the end of 2020, over 600 by 2021, and more than 800 by the mid-2020s. The venture faces competition from other companies like SpaceX and Boeing but believes it has a first-mover advantage. OneWeb is registered in the UK's Channel Islands and emphasizes the economic benefits for the UK. The project also addresses debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit satellites within two years to prevent space debris and potential collisions. Airbus and OneWeb hope their new manufacturing methods will influence the broader satellite industry, though not all satellite missions will adopt these techniques.

The passage discusses the financial pressures faced by the Scottish government due to the UK government's recent spending review and ongoing austerity measures. Mr. Swinney, the Scottish government official, highlights that the UK government's cuts since 2010, along with the latest spending review, will reduce Scotland's discretionary budget by 12.5% by 2019-20. Despite this, Swinney asserts that key services like schools, hospitals, and the police will not be compromised. The UK government counters that Scotland will have £390m more in spending next year, rising to £750m with underspend included, and emphasizes the stability of the UK economy. Labour's Jackie Baillie calls for a long-term budget approach and criticizes the Scottish government's anti-austerity posturing.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families due to the lack of suitable accessible toilet facilities, particularly Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced features and more space. Currently, these toilets are recommended but not compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers and cinemas. Campaigners, including Lorna Fillingham, are advocating for Changing Places toilets to be made compulsory in building regulations to ensure better accessibility. There are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but the need is much greater, with potentially over a quarter of a million people requiring such facilities. The passage highlights the psychological impact on families and the importance of accessibility for all customers, as demonstrated by positive reactions to Changing Places toilets in venues like Arsenal Football Club.

A group of Italian consumers' organizations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of imposing excessive rents and high fees on its franchisees. McDonald's maintains that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, which has been successful for many years. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and several European unions are supporting the complaint, urging the European Commission to investigate and hold McDonald's accountable. The Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are deemed credible. The complaint also claims that McDonald's prevents franchisees from switching to competitors by enforcing longer contracts and leasing premises at above-market rates, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, generating $9.27 billion in revenues from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A poster with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood, part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer after an operation intended for his appendix. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church and has since gone viral, garnering support from people worldwide. A mystery donor funded a billboard in Holywood playing fields, and the hashtag has been widely used on Twitter by Josh's classmates.

The passage discusses the UK government's decision to close Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Brecon, Wales, which has been in operation since 1805. Conservative MP Chris Davies strongly condemned the closure, highlighting its historical significance and the potential negative impact on the local economy, particularly military tourism and unemployment. Davies announced plans to fight the decision and launch a petition. The Defence Secretary, Sir Michael Fallon, mentioned the creation of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan and confirmed the closure dates for other sites in Wales. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the need for restructuring but expressed concern about the uncertainty faced by those affected.

The passage discusses the potential impacts of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. Fishing regions in the UK, which largely voted to leave the EU, are concerned about being marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which ensures equal access to fishing grounds for all member states, is often criticized by the UK fishing industry. Despite this, the House of Lords European Union Committee warns that the UK might need to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a Brexit deal. The report highlights that while the fishing industry is small in terms of GDP and employment, it must not be marginalized. The shared nature of commercial fish stocks between the UK and other EU states complicates the issue, as does the need for continued market access for UK fish exports. The report suggests that the UK may face trade-offs, such as allowing more EU access to UK waters in return for continued tariff-free sales to the EU. It also recommends retaining elements of the CFP post-Brexit and ensuring that fishing quotas are based on scientific advice. The potential fragmentation of fisheries management into four different regimes in the UK is noted as a concern. Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the opportunities Brexit presents, such as full control over the 200-mile exclusive economic zone and the potential for fairer and more sustainable fisheries management. The government aims to balance the freedom for British companies to trade with the EU while reviewing fisheries management for sustainability and a healthy marine environment.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, leaked documents revealing extensive US surveillance by the NSA, including access to chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The US government confirmed requesting millions of phone records from Verizon, including call details and locations. The leaked documents also indicated that the NSA's Prism program enabled "backdoor" access to servers of major tech companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, and Facebook, though these companies denied involvement. NSA Director Keith Alexander defended the operations as necessary for national security, while some experts questioned their true extent. Different countries have varying data protection laws, but these generally do not regulate government surveillance activities. Officials argue that preventing terrorism takes precedence over privacy. User data is often stored in the US, making it subject to US laws like the Patriot Act. The involvement of other governments in Prism remains unclear, though the EU expressed concern. Privacy International highlighted the global privacy implications of the Prism program, and Edward Snowden cited privacy concerns as his motivation for leaking the documents.

Open AI, backed by notable figures and companies such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to conduct research focused on achieving a "positive human impact" with no financial obligations. The venture emphasizes advancing digital intelligence to benefit humanity as a whole, while acknowledging the potential risks and threats posed by AI, as highlighted by figures like Stephen Hawking. Open AI's mission statement underscores the importance of safely and broadly distributing AI benefits, with only a small portion of the $1bn pledge to be spent initially.

In 2006, L/Bdr Parkinson was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan, resulting in a brain injury that affected his speech. Despite this, he has maintained his personality, sense of humor, intelligence, and wit. Since carrying the Olympic torch on 26 June, he has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, though the site limits personal pages to 5,000 friends. He spends 12 hours a day in gym and rehab, walks with crutches, and raises money for military charities and supports the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, noted the overwhelming support and friendship shown to Ben, with his page receiving 19,000 hits and thousands joining the Pilgrim Bandits website. Facebook suggested that Ben, having become a public figure, should consider having a page instead of a profile or using the subscribe feature for public updates. A total of 8,000 people will carry the Olympic flame during its 70-day, 8,000-mile journey to the London Olympic Games opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US remained at 15%, affecting 46.2 million Americans, after three years of increases. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of uninsured Americans dropped slightly to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, moved to Lancashire from Somerset in 2013 and signed a new deal until 2019. He holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent and contribution to the team's T20 Blast victory. Buttler, currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register interest in the ships, with viewings scheduled for late February and March. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports UK recyclers but also advocates for saving at least one frigate for a reef or diving attraction to generate tourism income. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers. The Type 22 frigates were originally designed for anti-submarine warfare but evolved into powerful surface combatants with various weapons systems and excellent command and control facilities.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant racial and political instability, marked by multiple coups and international isolation. The first coup in 1987, led by indigenous Fijians, overthrew an Indian-dominated government, followed by a constitution that favored indigenous Fijians. Another coup in 2000, led by George Speight, saw the hostage-taking of the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister and his cabinet, severely impacting the economy and international reputation. These events led to a military takeover in 2006, and Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to lack of progress towards democracy. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the latter group significantly decreasing due to emigration. Fiji's economy, reliant on sugar, tourism, mining, and services, faces persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a major recipient of international aid. Free elections in 2014 led to the restoration of full diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand and Fiji's re-instatement in the Commonwealth.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is making efforts to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timetable but missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Mekdad reported that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice en route to Latakia, with the second shipment intercepted by fire from terrorist groups. He criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported 246 deaths, including 73 children, in the last five days. Mekdad insisted that the government is defending against terrorist attacks and denied targeting civilians. Additionally, the Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that the Islamic Front coalition had freed hundreds of detainees. Syria has approximately 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% having left the country so far. The US and Russia have expressed concerns over the slow progress of the destruction process, with a new deadline set for 1 March for the transfer of chemical weapons to the coast for removal.

Mukherjee's "The Lives Of Others" is favored to win the Booker Prize, which is open to all English-language authors for the first time. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall. The shortlist includes former Booker winner Howard Jacobson, British writers Ali Smith and Joshua Ferris, Americans Karen Joy Fowler and Richard Flanagan, and Australian Flanagan. The prize marks its 46th year, with last year's winner being Eleanor Catton for "The Luminaries." Each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. The ceremony will be covered by the BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing to the UK Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant the appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the conclusion of the hearing. PJS, who has young children and a publicly known spouse, was previously granted anonymity due to his legal action against the publication of alleged extra-marital activities by The Sun on Sunday. The Court of Appeal had ruled that PJS was unlikely to maintain permanent anonymity as details of the allegations had become widespread. PJS's lawyers had been actively monitoring and removing stories in breach of the injunction, but the Court of Appeal deemed it a "hopeless task".

Fosse Park, a shopping center near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was recently purchased for £345.5 million. The new owners, in collaboration with Blaby District Council, are planning improvements to address parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, highlighted the potential for enhancing the view into the city, currently dominated by the backs of sheds. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, emphasized the need to improve common areas and facilities to ensure the location is as good as possible.

The much-anticipated film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving LeFou, the sidekick of the main antagonist Gaston. The film was approved for release by the Malaysian Censorship Board with a minor edit concerning the gay moment, but Disney decided to hold the release for a content review. Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia, although the country's tourism minister criticized the potential ban as "ridiculous." The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification." Local cinema chains began offering refunds for advance ticket purchases. The decision to review the film drew criticism from netizens, who found it "stupid and laughable." A new release date has not been announced.

Landlords in Southampton who let properties to more than three unrelated people must apply for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost up to £1,000, despite potential fines of up to £20,000 for non-compliance. Southampton City Council estimates there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Concerns from HMO tenants include fear of eviction and living in poorly maintained properties. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses with three or more storeys and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, specific areas are designated for HMO licensing. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance, although most landlords have cooperated with the licensing regime.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to prevent a second election. Fianna Fáil is willing to facilitate a minority government but won't support a government program. The primary issue in reaching an agreement is water charges. A commission to review the future of Irish Water is being considered. Fianna Fáil demands the immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael believes they have a role. After the recent election, Fine Gael secured 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7, but no party could form a majority government, and a taoiseach has not yet been elected.

The Sorrento, an Italian ferry en route to Valencia, experienced a severe fire on one of its car decks approximately 27km from Mallorca. The blaze quickly escalated, leading to a full evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, responded to the distress signals sent out at 13:50 local time. Rescued individuals were transported to safety and were being taken back to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were injured, with one reported to be seriously hurt and taken to the hospital by helicopter. The cause of the fire remains unclear, and there is a possibility that The Sorrento may sink. Spanish officials have requested psychologists to provide counseling at the port upon the passengers' arrival.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs identified individuals, including students, who claimed to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. The Commission suggested that individual electoral registers managed by councils should be better integrated to help identify duplicate entries. Labour cautioned against making it harder for young people to register to vote. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in voter registration applications, with 2.9 million received over a six-week period. However, concerns about duplicate applications persisted, with an estimated 30% to 70% of applications being duplicates in different areas. The Electoral Commission recommended clearer information on registration sites and a verification function to address this issue. Despite efforts to inform people that they did not need to re-register if they had already voted, the problem continued, and urgent action was needed. The Commission emphasized that while some people may lawfully register in more than one constituency for local elections, voting twice in a general election is an offense. Labour's shadow minister for voter engagement, Cat Smith, supported prosecuting those suspected of voting twice but warned against measures that could disproportionately affect young people and students.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star player at the University of Nebraska and NFL rookie, is believed to have killed himself while serving a prison term of over 30 years for multiple assault convictions. Phillips, who played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers, had a history of legal troubles. He was accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward, but took his own life before the trial could proceed. His former coach, Tom Osborne, noted Phillips' intelligence and good qualities but also his anger issues and inability to overcome personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal at an event in Chester, marking eight years of service. Awarded his honor by Brigadier Andrew Williams, he is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War. Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014, has an army number, is paid for his rations, and takes holidays during the mating season. He has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights and met Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool staged a remarkable comeback against Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League quarter-finals, winning 4-3 after trailing 2-0 early on. Dejan Lovren's injury-time header secured the victory, echoing the spirit of Liverpool's 2005 Champions League triumph. The match was marked by intense emotion, drama, and Klopp's passionate touchline presence. Liverpool's resilience and belief, inspired by Klopp, turned doubt into belief, moving them closer to a potential Champions League return. The atmosphere at Anfield was electric, with fans singing "You'll Never Walk Alone" and observing a minute's silence for the Hillsborough disaster. Despite some defensive vulnerabilities, Liverpool's performance showcased Klopp's impact and the team's growing confidence.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK's David Davis proposed monthly meetings to share analysis with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, aiming for a "two-way information flow" during Brexit negotiations. However, Scotland's Nicola Sturgeon emphasized the need for transparency regarding the UK government's strategic intentions, particularly concerning the single market and customs union, which she deemed essential for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes to overturn a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50, while the Scottish government plans to oppose this in the Supreme Court.

Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr is examining Daisy, a cloned sheep from the University of Nottingham, for signs of heat, swelling, crepitus, or lameness that might indicate disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is one of 13 cloned sheep, and one of four cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly the sheep, making them identical twins. The study aims to determine if cloned animals age normally and how healthy they are, addressing concerns that "age-memory" might be transferred during cloning, potentially causing cloned animals to develop age-related diseases prematurely. Dolly died at six-and-a-half years old from a virus-induced lung condition and osteoarthritis, raising questions about the cloning process. The study involves extensive tests, including joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published soon, but the cloned sheep currently appear healthy as they approach their ninth and tenth birthdays.

Trainer John Gosden's unbeaten 4-7 favorite, Shutter Speed, won comfortably in challenging conditions and will head to France's Oaks at Chantilly instead of the Oaks at Epsom, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Gosden is uncertain about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will decide whether to run him based on a course walk. Shutter Speed is in good form and will prepare for Chantilly, while the short gap between the Dante Stakes and the Derby may prevent Cracksman from participating in the Dante Stakes.

The currency initially slipped against the dollar and euro but recovered before falling again. The "volatility index" has reached levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. The pound weakened by 0.2% against the dollar, 0.6% against the euro, and 1% against the yen. Investors are concerned about the chances of a Remain vote decreasing and global economic worries. With 10 days before the referendum, polls show the Leave camp ahead, and the implied probability of a vote to Remain has fallen to 68.5%. Analysts expect more aggressive movement in the pound based on incoming polls. Asian stock markets fell significantly, and the FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%. Despite the pound's recent weakening, Leave campaigner Nigel Farage noted that it has been strengthening since March and is beneficial for UK exporters.

The Iron, currently sixth in the National League, are one point and one place away from the play-off spots. Despite a tough match against a strong Barrow team, Braintree manager Cowley praised his team's performance and remained positive about their journey. Barrow won, extending their unbeaten league run to nine games, while Braintree's losing streak reached three games. Cowley acknowledged the challenges of being a part-time team but expressed determination to embrace and enjoy the difficulties.

The passage discusses a significant change in Northern Ireland's planning system, where from April 2015, local councils will take over the responsibility for planning decisions from the Planning Service, except for the most significant ones. This shift means elected politicians will make most planning decisions, a move that has both supporters and critics. Michael Corr, the creative director of PLACE, sees it as a positive opportunity for councils to develop community plans. However, concerns are raised about the potential for discrimination and favoritism, as seen in the 1960s, and the need for strict enforcement of a code of conduct to ensure fairness. Friends of the Earth warns of the danger of close relationships between developers and political parties, emphasizing the importance of transparency in political donations. Some local politicians oppose the move due to potential security concerns for donors, while others argue that the current donation limit is not relevant to Northern Ireland's political landscape.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times—twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, which had to be amputated. Teenie's owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. The Scottish SPCA called Teenie "incredibly lucky" to survive and highlighted the need for air weapon licensing. Last year, the Scottish government consulted on licensing air weapons, but most responders opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA urged anyone with information about the incident to contact them.

Christian Benteke has become Liverpool's second most expensive signing on a long-term contract, following the sale of Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. Benteke, a Belgium international, scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa after joining from Genk for £7m in 2012. Liverpool, who finished sixth in the Premier League last season, triggered a release clause in Benteke's contract to make him their seventh summer signing. The club aims to revive their attack after struggling for goals last season, with manager Brendan Rodgers adding Benteke to the squad alongside forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge believe Benteke will be a valuable addition to the team.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that while tablet computers are increasingly prevalent in schools, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them, there is no clear evidence of academic improvement linked to their use. Tablets are most commonly used in academy schools. Despite the lack of definitive academic benefits, head teachers reported a positive impact, particularly in motivating disengaged pupils and increasing family involvement. The study also highlighted the pervasive role of technology in young people's lives, with many taking devices to bed for social media and video use. Additionally, a separate study suggested that touch-screen computers, including tablets, are particularly beneficial for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. The overall trend indicates a growing integration of technology in education, reflecting both school environments and the technological landscape of students' homes and future workplaces.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs capturing children's lives over more than 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s. Curated by Kay Jones, these images provide a social history of Liverpool, illustrating changes in childhood and special occasions. The oldest photograph is from 1887, depicting the Rollo children at a fancy dress ball. The exhibition also highlights children's work, showing a young maid around 1900. Jones selected the images to represent both positive and negative childhood experiences. The exhibition runs until 25 September.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival, potentially facing his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams, is set to join the Gulls pending international clearance, having previously played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson praised Anderson's leadership and Keating's hunger. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone with only one win in their last six games.

Bolivia has enacted a new law permitting 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, reflecting the country's economic needs despite international standards suggesting children under 15 should not work. The legislation imposes a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide and was signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales. The law aims to address extreme poverty, as over 500,000 children already work to support their families, often in harsh conditions. The International Labour Organisation is reviewing the law to determine if it complies with international child labor regulations.

A 50-year-old woman, after experiencing symptoms of a heart attack such as sudden nausea and aches, researched "women's heart attack symptoms" online and took aspirin. She visited a cardiologist who found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. The woman, who did not call emergency services, referred to her heart attack as the "widow maker" in a blog post, urging her readers to recognize symptoms and call 911. She is a former actress and TV host whose show was recently canceled due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed during a scuffle in an alleyway near a party in Kenton, London, after a group of youths attempted to gain entry. The party was described as well-run with appropriate adults present, and Che was not involved in the initial altercation. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, while two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested and bailed, and a 14-year-old boy is held on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

The passage discusses Denmark's reorganization of its cancer diagnosis system to address poor survival statistics and long waiting times, particularly for less obvious cancer cases. The new approach includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with specific "alarm" symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with undiagnosable symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. These changes have improved survival rates and better organized patient diagnosis within existing resources. Wales, which has a similar health system, could potentially learn from Denmark's experience.

Powys council has been selected to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents, replacing the disbanded Office of Fair Trading (OFT). They will receive £170,000 annually for this service. Complaints about estate agents will still be directed to local authority trading standards, but cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, hopes this role will demonstrate Powys' capability for additional contracts and external work.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to retrain and redeploy healthcare staff to address shortages and improve patient care. The Nuffield Trust review found that nurses and pharmacists could take on additional tasks with more training, such as filling in for doctors. However, unions caution against using this as a quick fix for broader NHS issues, emphasizing the need for adequate funding and support for both healthcare staff and doctors. The report highlights the changing nature of care, focusing more on managing long-term conditions. While there are opportunities to improve patient care and staff roles, concerns remain about the quality of doctor training and the chronic shortages of healthcare workers.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot following a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays during rush hour until the road reopened at 14:00 GMT. Investigations into the collision are ongoing. First reported that while some services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. Managing director James Freeman expressed hope for a full service in time for the evening commute and thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts.

The passage discusses a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) regarding the environmental impact of the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW estimated that the lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die annually during migration. TLP contested these figures, arguing they lacked a "clear scientific basis" and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own computer modeling estimated a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality. The project, valued at £1.3bn, is seen as a test for larger lagoons along the coast. The UK government is reviewing the scheme's viability, while the Welsh Government expresses support but seeks clarity on the UK government's stance. NRW maintains its figures are based on the "best available evidence" and has shared extensive information with TLP.

The passage discusses the announcement by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster about the creation of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. This body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities, similar to the successful Scotland Food and Drink. The agri-food industry in Northern Ireland is significant, supporting nearly 100,000 jobs across various sectors. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill supports the initiative, emphasizing the sector's role in economic growth, but also notes potential implications for other organizations, including her department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a public tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1, with a specific tribute to the 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives. The project, part of a larger initiative to plant millions of native UK trees, involves planting 40,000 trees over four years. Volunteers are invited to participate, with saplings provided by the charity. The event aims to create a space for wildlife and reflection, with wildflowers and iconic poppies planned for the area. The project site is located about seven miles outside Derry city, with limited parking available.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for "Someone Else's Skin," a novel tackling domestic violence and honour crime. US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career and creation of the strong female protagonist, VI Warshawski. The awards were presented at the North Yorkshire crime writing festival, where the shortlist was noted as particularly strong.

Mitch Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner, suffered a finger injury in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant setback for the team's hopes of qualifying. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, will return to Worcestershire following the ICC Trophy in June. Steve Rhodes, the director of cricket, expressed that there is unfinished business with Santner and looks forward to his impact next season. Additionally, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

In 2008, Barry Pring, 47, was killed by a speeding car with stolen license plates on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (also known as Anna), had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that Barry's guard was lowered due to inebriation and the car did not brake or stop. The case is considered circumstantial but the evidence is deemed overwhelming. Friends and family believe Ziuzina was involved in the staged hit-and-run to inherit Pring's assets. The Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but relaunched it as a murder investigation in 2011. The case remains active but is not being actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns, from Merseyside, urgently needs to fly her son Charlie to Seattle, USA, for experimental T-Cell Therapy unavailable in the UK. After the last transplant failed, Charlie requires more treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital. The family was left heartbroken by the unsuccessful first transplant but received overwhelming support from an anonymous donor who covered the costs. Charlie, who has been ill since the age of three, experienced a third relapse in April, leaving no other treatment options in the UK. The family is extremely grateful for the anonymous donation and is awaiting confirmation of the treatment date.

Apple has implemented changes to its iCloud security to prevent third-party software from stealing intimate photos of celebrities, following reports of such thefts. The new security measure, two-step verification, adds an extra step for account access on new devices, requiring a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app. This process blocks access to iCloud and Apple services if the code is not entered correctly. A 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access if the trusted device is lost or stolen, but it must be kept safe. While Apple previously offered two-step verification, it was not previously applied to the backup service, allowing attackers to download complete data backups. The owner of Elcomsoft, a software believed to have been used in the hacks, acknowledged that Apple's changes prevent his software from functioning as before. However, concerns remain about the security system, particularly the potential for losing the recovery key. Some experts argue that two-factor authentication should be the default option for all companies, not just an opt-in choice. Apple plans to encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town are not yet released. Wright, a former non-league football player and reality TV contestant, is expected to become a club director. Billericay Town, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is three points away from a play-off spot. The club was recently acquired by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 a week, and has signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr. Ashley has been asked to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers, following a BBC investigation into Sports Direct's warehouse practices. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, sent a letter to Mr. Ashley, inviting him to a public meeting at the company's Shirebrook base to discuss low-paid worker treatment and minimum wage enforcement. Mr. Ashley has until 21 March to respond and agree to a meeting date. Failure to respond may result in the committee seeking House of Commons support for a contempt complaint. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request, although the company previously pledged to review worker rights under Mr. Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report titled "Putin. War," completed by colleagues of murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, led by Ilya Yashin. The report compiles facts from Russian and foreign media since the annexation of Crimea in 2014 and the conflict in eastern Ukraine, arguing that President Vladimir Putin is waging war for personal gain. It presents evidence that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial to rebel victories in Donetsk and Luhansk, and that Russian generals directed the main battles. The report also documents Russian military spending on the conflict and the salaries of volunteer soldiers. Despite the availability of these facts online and in some media, the opposition struggles to gain public attention for their findings, partly due to fear among relatives of dead soldiers and reluctance from publishers. The opposition accuses Putin of using the war to boost his popularity, a strategy they admit has been successful.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire with head injuries. He was 34 years old and from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham. A man, 41, and a woman, 23, were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police in connection with the case and remain in custody.

The passage discusses disagreements between the UK government and the Welsh government regarding the handling of Brexit negotiations, particularly the drafting and content of the Article 50 letter. Carwyn Jones, the first minister of Wales, expressed frustration over not being consulted on the letter and feeling disrespected by the process. Despite this, the UK government, represented by Alun Cairns, emphasized acting in the interests of the whole UK, with Wales being specifically mentioned in the letter. The letter mentions a consultation process on the return of powers to the UK, with an expectation of increased decision-making power for devolved administrations. However, specific details about which powers will be devolved and whether funding will follow remain unclear. The passage ends with a mention of potential further details in a white paper on the Great Repeal Bill.

Two cars were damaged in an incident involving PSNI officers in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay over the attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were performing their duties when they were attacked and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was ousted due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board stated in a San Francisco court filing that they do not expect him to return. His lawyer claims many statements are false and accuses the company of invading his privacy. Court filings include evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts by Mr. Charney. The company asserts his conduct violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board believes the risk of hiring him again is too great. Recently, the company obtained a restraining order against Mr. Charney, preventing him from making negative statements and attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses a basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The teams previously played in Patras, Greece, where Greece won 92-64. Three members of the Greek team will not be present for the rematch at the Copper Box in London, potentially giving GB a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at the Copper Box and highlighted the importance of this match in preparing for EuroBasket 2017. This game is Britain's only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which begins in September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey. Following the Greece match, GB will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before EuroBasket.

The passage recounts the author's experience witnessing the unveiling of the iPhone by Steve Jobs and the subsequent impact of the smartphone on society. Initially, the author was skeptical about the iPhone's significance but later recognized its revolutionary potential. The iPhone, with its attractive user interface, transformed photography and various other activities by making powerful computing accessible to billions. The author contrasts a poorly taken photo from 2007 with a much better one from 2017, both taken by the same person but with different devices, highlighting the iPhone's impact on photography and communication. The author concludes by acknowledging the iPhone's historical importance as the catalyst for the mobile-connected era and notes the ongoing innovation by companies like Amazon and Google.

A charity confirmed that several cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have ingested a toxic substance, resulting in multiple cat deaths. Seven-month-old Meereen died after consuming antifreeze, and three other cats died in the last seven days, with another cat dying two weeks ago. The RSPCA is uncertain whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is urging the community to store pesticides and chemicals safely. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock emphasized the importance of checking for leaks and cleaning up spills properly, especially during the time when antifreeze is commonly used.

The passage discusses the paradoxical situation in Greece where, despite the Syriza government agreeing to implement further austerity and liberalization measures, there are no protests in the streets. Instead, Greece's resorts are bustling with tourists. The government's acceptance of these measures, which they previously opposed, is attributed to the country's near-death economic experience in July. Although Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras remains popular, Greece faces severe economic challenges, including VAT increases, pension cuts, and monetary austerity due to the partial closure of banks. The passage concludes by emphasizing that for the new bailout to lead to genuine recovery, creditors, particularly Germany, must show debt forgiveness and avoid triumphalism.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, will briefly return to EastEnders for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Peggy, who returned after leaving in 2010, announced her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in emotional spring scenes. Kemp's return aims to reunite the Mitchell family, including his on-screen brother Phil, played by Steve McFadden. Grant Mitchell, a memorable EastEnders character since 1990, was involved in significant family dramas, including affairs and marriages with his brother's wives. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlights the importance of the Mitchell brothers reuniting to face their mother's passing.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recognized Dhillon as the attacker when informed by police. Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice, leading to the tragic incident. Dr. Hills expressed guilt for reassuring Alice over the phone, thinking the situation was not serious. The parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.
