This passage tells the story of a piglet born without back legs that has become an internet sensation for learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," lives with farmer Ms. Duan in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China. Despite its disability, the piglet balances well, mixes with its littermates, and forages for food with its snout to the ground. A video of the piglet's journey has captured the hearts of thousands. This isn't the first animal in China with such a condition to gain attention; a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became famous for walking on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member named Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box on lap 25 for tires and fuel, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment, received stitches for a cut on his leg, and was later released. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to prior rain. Dracone did not finish the race, placing 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. The incident was captured on CCTV. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating his motive was jealousy over men looking at his wife. Cicera belonged to a dance troop called Jaula das Gostozuedas. After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car but was arrested by police following a crash. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car. He now faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," shared her personal struggle with mental illness in a candid interview. She revealed that anxiety and other issues, including stress, thyroid disease, and feeling isolated, led her to believe her life was not worth living and she came close to taking her own life. Wilson emphasized the link between depression and anxiety, suggesting that anxiety is becoming the "new depression." She advocates for acknowledging this connection to better address the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. Wilson now accepts her anxiety but feels she missed out on understanding how others coped. For help, she directs people to contact Beyond Blue or Lifeline.

Elena Curtin, a 23-year-old woman from Portland, Oregon, who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault after she assaulted her boyfriend's former girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. She found the woman using heroin in her bathroom and attacked her when the woman refused to leave. Oregon law permits the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating that Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." The incident led Curtin to reflect on her relationship and she has since moved on, giving birth in January and now living with her parents. The boyfriend, who has a history of heroin addiction and a child with the ex-girlfriend, has not been involved in the life of Curtin's newborn.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed refusing to eat broccoli, showing a disgusted reaction and spitting it out. This behavior raises concerns about whether the children she lives with will also refuse vegetables. Despite this, Gemma enjoys treats, sleeping, and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized for a link on its official website that directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link, intended for the Young Entrepreneur Awards page, was compromised after the awards were discontinued in 2011 and the registration was allowed to expire. Visitors were instead greeted by explicit content. HSBC removed the link upon realizing the mistake and issued a public apology, clarifying that it had no association with the external site. The bank emphasized that its website remained secure and continued to offer various services to customers.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 when his family's home caught fire on Sunday morning. He provided firefighters with instructions during the 11-minute call, helping to rescue himself and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah, who were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus stayed calm, soothed his sister, and gave clear directions to the dispatcher. Firefighters broke a window to enter the room and rescued the siblings. They were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped on their own and were taken to Medstar Hospital.

Amazing pictures of blue fluorescent algae have emerged, lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar phenomenon occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. The glow is caused by Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, typically due to natural causes. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the algae emit light as a defense mechanism while preying on diatoms.

New genetic tests can identify markers in breast cancer tumors to determine their aggressiveness, potentially sparing some patients from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened in a lab, and women can learn within days if they have a high or low risk of recurrence. For some, the risk can be as low as five percent, comparable to or better than the odds with chemotherapy. Currently, most breast cancer patients receive chemotherapy post-surgery to prevent recurrence, despite its severe side effects. However, experts believe that for some women, chemotherapy may not be necessary. Tests like Endopredict can show a low score, allowing patients to opt out of chemotherapy. Most of these tests are privately available at a cost of about £2,500, but there is hope they may become available on the NHS. Experts argue that the cost is balanced by savings from avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy. These tests enable patients to make informed choices, unlike the past when chemotherapy was given to almost everyone.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean over the last nine years. At least one woman was evacuated from HMS Illustrious, nicknamed "HMS Lusty," before its decommissioning. Eighteen other ships, such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A strict "no touching" rule at sea suggests the women conceived before boarding or during leave. This follows the case of Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, who was flown back for alleged misconduct. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after discovering they were pregnant, with 99 servicewomen evacuated between 2006 and 2013. An additional 102 women were evacuated from Iraq. Military rules prohibit mothers-to-be from serving in war zones.

A drone containing traces of a radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was discovered on the rooftop of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's residence in Tokyo. The drone, equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle with the radioactive substance, was found on the same day a Japanese court approved the restart of two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant. The incident has raised concerns about potential terrorism involving drones, especially with the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. The government is reviewing measures to prevent such threats, although current laws only restrict drone flights around airports.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province in China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him on the back of his motorbike every day. He is concerned she might get lost if left alone, as she used to wander off when collecting firewood. With his wife working in another city and his son still in school, Lu feels responsible for his mother's care. He ensures her safety by tying a sash around their waists and checks on her at work, where she has a room provided by his employers. Lu rides slowly to work to allow for conversation and feels reassured only when he sees his mother.

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking and binge drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012. Heavy drinking is defined as more than one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The increase is largely due to rising rates among women as social norms change. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. Despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time. The study also found that the rate of binge drinking among women increased more than seven times the rate among men. The increase in excessive drinking is attributed to cultural and economic factors, such as changed social norms, the influx of wealthy professionals in cities, and weakened alcohol control policies.

UN officials warn that doctors are putting the health of women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too readily. They emphasize that the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary due to potential infections and other health risks. Currently, just over a quarter of women giving birth in England have a caesarean, a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s. This includes an increasing number of women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural childbirth. However, experts from the World Health Organization suggest that the ideal rate should be between 10% and 15% due to the associated dangers and costs. They highlight that while caesareans can save lives, they are often performed without medical need, leading to short- and long-term health problems. The WHO statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow for the procedure even without medical justification.

Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested for breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. She allegedly broke into a home on Martha's Vineyard, lived there for at least a week, and sold items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. Filkins was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, on April 17. She fled but was later arrested when she tried to re-enter the home. Missing items include furniture, a grill, lamps, and a painting. Police are asking anyone who received these items to return them and are seeking restitution for victims.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with its owner after Albury police officers posted a series of humorous photos and messages on Bella's Facebook page. The phone was handed in at Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border. Recognizing the phone was unlocked, officers posted selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the station on Bella's Facebook page, encouraging her to collect it. Bella lost her phone at a friend's birthday party and realized it was missing when she dialed her number. A security guard at the party said they would leave it at the police station. Bella arrived at the station later and found her friends had already responded humorously to the posts. The officers reassured Bella that her phone was safe and fully charged. Bella did not need to provide her name when she reclaimed her phone as officers recognized her from her Facebook page. Bella appreciated the police's good humor and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa. The helpless calf was thrown into the air and subsequently dragged along the water's surface, ultimately dying from its injuries. The calf's mother watched in horror but stayed with her herd, possibly believing it to be safer. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the tragic event, noting the mother's attempts to protect her baby and the fatal outcome.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000, significantly less than neighboring properties. However, the property has only three years left on its lease, making it a risky investment. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The unmodernized maisonette, located in the exclusive Egerton Place, offers 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, a utility room, lift access, parking, and a communal garden. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson, with another similar property on Egerton Place listed for £595,000. The next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge is priced at £1.5 million and comes with a 28-year lease. Potential buyers should be aware that extending the lease could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year lease.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, leading baristas to give away free drinks. The outage, which began on Friday evening, was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. The company resolved the issue and expected stores to open for normal business on Saturday. The outage affected 7,000 US stores and 1,000 Canadian stores, and Starbucks did not provide details on the exact cause. Customers took to social media to share their experiences, with many locations closing early or entirely to avoid giving away free products. The incident occurred just a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings with net revenues of $4.6 billion.

Terrorists are undergoing training and radicalization in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These individuals participate in ordinary community activities while having ulterior motives. Historical incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales date back to 1998, and notable events include the training of 7/7 bombers in the Brecon Beacons and the study of Arabic by one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby at a former institute in Llanybydder. Community intelligence is emphasized as vital for authorities.

An Omura's whale, a species feared to be extinct and only described in scientific journals in 2003, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The juvenile female whale was identified through DNA profiling. The discovery is highly significant for scientists as it provides an opportunity to learn more about the species, which is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possibly for public display in museums.

The passage discusses the notion that hormones, particularly in women, are considered a factor in presidential candidates' decision-making, exemplified by comments from Cheryl Rios, a businesswoman who believes Hillary Clinton's hormones might lead her to start an unnecessary war. Rios argues that women should not be president due to their hormones, despite historical evidence showing male hormones have impaired male leaders' decisions. Studies indicate women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than men. The passage also highlights gender bias against women in the workplace, noting that even in 2015, a female candidate faces significant challenges due to established biases. It emphasizes that gender equality benefits everyone, including stronger economies, happier and healthier children, and better corporate results. The article concludes by pointing out the irony in Rios's stance, given that Canada already had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is auctioning his extensive antique collection, valued at £100,000, to downsize his home. The auction includes over 200 items, such as a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, early Victorian furniture, a longbow, and various paintings and books. Hardy, an expert on medieval history and military history, studied with J.R.R. Tolkien and has published books on the longbow. The auction, conducted by Dominic Winter Auctioneers, features 238 lots and will take place in Gloucestershire. Hardy expressed sadness at parting with his collection but hopes the new owners will enjoy it as much as he did.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted by authorities as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57, who was found dead in their shared Winter Garden home. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the day of the murder. He is already on parole for battery on law enforcement, has a history of bipolar mental illness, and was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide. Neighbors believe the stress of his divorce proceedings may have contributed to the crime. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not disclosed the cause of death. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication. His estranged wife is taking precautions in case he attempts to contact her. Anyone with information on his whereabouts is asked to contact authorities at 407-656-3636.

Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The decision by the IAAF Council bypassed the usual bidding process due to a perceived "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously failed to secure the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council's decision was influenced by a recent presentation that convinced them of Eugene's capability to host the championships. IAAF President Lamine Diack highlighted the collaborative efforts of public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the public in making this choice. This decision mirrors the 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, which also did not follow the typical bidding process.

An aspiring model, Leonie Granger, 25, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, into a honey trap at a London casino. Granger befriended Hassan, who was known for flashing large sums of money, and convinced him to take her home. She left the door unlocked, allowing her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, 28, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, 29, to enter. They tied up Hassan, beat him to death, and stole his cash. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas has struggled during the second half of the season, notably in Spain's 2-0 defeat by Holland. Despite a strong start, his form has declined, raising questions about his durability. Fabregas captained Spain in the match but failed to make a significant impact. His performance has been a concern for Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho, especially as the team needs him to regain form to secure the Premier League title. Fabregas' former club Barcelona noted a trend of his declining performance towards the end of each season, a pattern that seems to be continuing. Despite his recent struggles, Fabregas has the potential to break Thierry Henry's record of 20 assists in a Premier League season, a personal goal that could also benefit Chelsea's title bid.

West Ham is negotiating a deal for Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old talent from Montego Bay United, who has impressed during a trial with the club's academy. Beckford, considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean, has also received offers from clubs in Belgium. Meanwhile, West Ham announced that season tickets for their move to the Olympic Stadium in the 2016-17 season will start at £289, aiming to have the cheapest pricing in the Barclays Premier League to fill the 54,000 capacity stadium.

Police have dropped the investigation into the assault on Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman, despite having a video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers of the saboteurs. The attack occurred on January 24 near Amesbury, where Lane was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes, resulting in concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Wiltshire Police confirmed they stopped the investigation due to insufficient evidence but will reopen it if new information surfaces. Lane and other hunt supporters are dismayed by the decision, with some losing trust in the police. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to facilitate easier identification and prosecution.

Adam Gadahn, a U.S. citizen known as the American mouthpiece for Al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January. He was a prominent member of Al Qaeda, serving as its chief English-language propagandist and appearing in numerous videos threatening attacks on the U.S. and other Western targets. Gadahn, who converted to Islam and left the U.S. for Pakistan in 1998, was indicted for treason and material support to Al Qaeda in 2006. He was not specifically targeted in the operation that killed him, but two hostages, including U.S. citizen Warren Weinstein, also died in the attack.

Chinese parents are passionate about raising child prodigies, exemplified by a new basketball superstar, five-year-old Mai Zizhuo. A viral video showcases Mai's impressive basketball skills, which he has been practicing since he was two and a half years old. The video shows him scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously, earning him fans across basketball-mad China. Mai's talent has drawn comparisons to China's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming, and has left netizens in awe, with many questioning how he developed such skills at such a young age.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key activist for PIE, attended a Hacked Off rally on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation and advocates for a statutory body to regulate the press as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off is an embarrassment to the group. PIE, formed in 1974, aimed to legalize sex with children and allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties, which lobbied for reducing the age of sexual consent to ten if the child understood the act and consented. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals" and confirmed his attendance at the Hacked Off meeting, which was open to the public.

On Thursday, Bondi's iconic Icebergs Club drained its pool to serve as an unusual catwalk for the Ten Pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event featured a collection of ten unisex clothing pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models paraded through the empty pool and along the break wall, with a stunning ocean backdrop. The show attracted crowds who watched from the club's balcony and the road above. Guests enjoyed nibbles from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria while taking in the minimalist, androgynous designs. The event took place on a warm day with beautiful blue skies and sunshine.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, enjoyed a family trip to a safari park in Northern California, where he posed with animals including a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. He was accompanied by his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and their daughter, Lamya. Earlier, Khan announced that his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was killed by three Israelis, had his name placed on an Israeli memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl. His family and Almagor, an organization representing terror victims in Israel, objected to his inclusion. They argued that his death was a rogue attack and not representative of terror victims. Following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove his name from the memorial.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son chasing their cat around the garden to rest his head on the cat. The footage shows the cat initially allowing the boy to rest on it, but the cat quickly moves away each time. This sequence repeats until the cat decides to leave indoors. Later, the boy and the cat reconcile, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

In an ongoing police corruption trial in Philadelphia, witness Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer and varsity basketball coach at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy, lost his coaching job after testifying about his past involvement in selling marijuana. Kushner, 32, testified that undercover officers on trial had stolen $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Despite passing a background check when hired in 2010, his past criminal activities were revealed during the trial, leading to his dismissal. Kushner maintains that he never intended to deceive the school and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges. The trial involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, with the defense arguing that the case is based on lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China, injured six people and caused a large fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast happened at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill has been reported. Five of the injured were hurt by broken glass and were hospitalized. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze. Residents nearby reported hearing the explosion and shared photos of the fire on social media. The plant had a previous explosion in July 2013 with no casualties or toxic leaks. The construction of PX plants has led to protests in several Chinese cities due to pollution concerns. The Zhangzhou plant was originally planned for Xiamen but was relocated due to public backlash.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player, has a superstition of wearing his socks just above his shinpads, specifically using children's shinpads, which he intends to maintain despite referee advice. He made his first Premier League start for Aston Villa in a 3-3 draw against QPR, expressing satisfaction with the opportunity despite the game's outcome.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. Although she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and does not respond to visitors or familiar voices. She has a tracheostomy in her throat and her eyes do not follow people around the room. Despite earlier reports of improvement by her father, Bobby Brown, who claimed she was awake and watching him, Cissy Houston and a source with knowledge of Brown's condition confirmed that she remains in the same neurological state she has been in for nearly three months. Doctors have indicated that she will have a long life, but the quality of her life remains uncertain as she embarks on a long and hard rehabilitation process.

Russia is on the brink of making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Germany's Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's powerful play and had 13 double faults, but Lisicki's 63 unforced errors were crucial. Russia needs one more win from Sunday's matches to reach the final and secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit the region later this week. Meteorologists indicate that an east coast low, similar to the one that caused three days of severe weather last week, could impact the area with heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that additional storms will hamper ongoing clean-up efforts from the previous storm, with over 4,000 jobs still pending from 24,196 requests for assistance. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills emphasized the need for the community to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation, particularly in the Hunter region, which was severely affected by the last storm. Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott noted that a trough of low pressure is forming along the coast, with the heaviest impact expected in the far northern parts of the state. The Bureau of Meteorology's NSW regional director, Barry Hanstrum, stated that early indications suggest the main impacts will be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, with heavy rainfall also expected for southeast Queensland.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, has denied claims that she attempted suicide. She posted photos of her bruises on Instagram, explaining that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure after a fall. Italian media reported that her boyfriend suggested she tried to commit suicide, but Moric clarified that she was fine and needed rest. She also mentioned that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time of the incident. Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, a famous Italian paparazzi who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a YouGov survey for The Sunday Times shows that the British public hopes for a traditional name. If the baby is a girl, "Diana" is the favorite name, chosen by 12% of those polled, in honor of William's mother, Diana, Princess of Wales. "Alice" and "Charlotte" follow with 9% each. For a boy, "James" is the top choice at 13%, followed by "Alexander." A quarter of those polled prefer a girl, while only 3% hope for another boy. Social media reflects these preferences, with many users expressing hope for the name "Diana." Additionally, 68% of respondents support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time as the protesters were on their way to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed it. The report was contributed to by CNN journalists Masoud Popalzai, Jethro Mullen, and Elizabeth Joseph.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. The Brazilian right-back, who has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice, was unable to agree on a new deal. His agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed at a press conference that Alves had turned down a three-year contract extension contingent on participating in 60% of matches. The negotiations are now concluded.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes that Pirlo and Totti, with their South American-style play, would be a perfect fit for Boca Juniors and that the fans would adore them. He emphasized that while he has played with many great players, Pirlo and Totti would be his top picks to join him at Boca Juniors.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, received no special treatment at Paul Nicholls' yard after a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square at Wincanton, which went viral online. Despite the fall, Ferguson only sustained a cut on his nose and was back riding out the next day. He described the fall as a blur and watched the replay to understand what had happened. Ferguson received some abuse but also gained new Twitter followers, and jokingly considered a gymnastics career after finishing racing.

James Haskell, a rugby player for the London Wasps, posted a picture of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram to celebrate the release of the movie "Avengers: Age of Ultron." The movie premiered at Westfield London Shopping Centre with an A-list cast including Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell, who has played rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand, returned to the Wasps in 2012 and has since surpassed 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England.

The passage discusses the emerging trend of wide leg trousers for the Spring/Summer 2015 season. It highlights the appeal of wide leg trousers as an alternative to the long-standing popularity of skinny jeans. The trend is versatile, available in various styles such as denim, cropped, printed, or striped. Louise Redknapp and Emma both endorse the trend, suggesting that pairing wide leg trousers with high heels and simple tops can create a flattering and stylish look. Proportion is key, and denim is noted as the easiest fabric to achieve this trend. High-street brands like Topshop and online labels like Finery London offer affordable options. The trend has been showcased on several catwalks, including Gucci and Celine, and can be styled for both casual and dressier occasions.

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. Over 200 students signed a petition against showing the movie as part of UMIX, a series of social events. Bradley Cooper was nominated for an Oscar for his role as Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history, who was killed in 2013. Some students felt the film's depiction of the Iraq War negatively portrayed the Middle East and its people. However, there was backlash against the initial decision to cancel the movie, leading to a counter-petition. University of Michigan's Vice President for Student Life, E. Royster Harper, stated that canceling the movie was a mistake and inconsistent with the university's values of freedom of expression and respect for students' choices. The university will also offer a screening of "Paddington" for those who prefer not to attend "American Sniper." Michigan's head football coach, Jim Harbaugh, praised the announcement.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, attempted to set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka survived but was singed. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, and charged both with animal cruelty. They were evicted from the island and are set to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

With the help of filmmakers, 102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer at New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, was able to see herself dancing for the first time. Barker, who had never seen any of the motion pictures made of her or her lost photographs and memorabilia, was shown a video of early music videos called "Soundies" by Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers at her nursing home. She was delighted, saying, "It's just fabulous."

A recent study by vehicle leasing firm OSV reveals that the tradition of washing one's own car in Britain is declining. The survey of 1,100 adults found that a third of men have never washed their own car, and only 12% of those who do it regularly. Additionally, three-quarters of women never wash their own car, with many opting to use local car washes instead. Factors contributing to this decline include the availability of hand car washes, larger vehicles, and busier schedules. Despite this trend, car owners are most likely to wash their cars during holidays, with Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield being the top cities for weekly car washing. OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley notes that while car washing used to be a national tradition, modern conveniences and busier lifestyles have contributed to its decline.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since Gerrard's arrival at Anfield in 2008, crediting Gerrard for helping him settle at the club. Skrtel believes Gerrard is synonymous with Liverpool and considers him one of the best players in the world. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal, which will mark his final Anfield appearance before moving to LA Galaxy. Skrtel acknowledges that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but believes the team has potential replacements and can work as a unit to fill the void left by Gerrard's departure.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, marking his first ace on the hallowed turf of Augusta. Playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, Nicklaus' achievement was part of a day that saw five hole-in-ones, equaling the 2002 record. Although Camilo Villegas also had multiple aces, he lost to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, who became the youngest person to wear a green jacket in 1963 and collected his sixth in 1986, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as multiple storms brought reports of tornadoes. Spotters reported a tornado 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, which moved northeast, missing the city but posing risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of continuous storms throughout the night, emphasizing the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, and a possible tornado was noted in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. Hail the size of baseballs was reported in Farmington. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for the fatal shooting of Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. Bates was granted permission to vacation in the Bahamas, which the Harris family criticized as a sign of apathy. Bates, 73, claims the shooting was accidental and has apologized to the Harris family. His lawyers argue he had proper training, while the Harris family's lawyer claims Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and connections. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. Ahead of the fight, McGregor has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger's face on his stomach, with a caption stating, "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor also has a gorilla eating a heart tattoo on his chest. McGregor claims he has more motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time. The two fighters have a contentious relationship, highlighted by an incident in Dublin where McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott faced criticism from anti-drinking campaigners for skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, which they believe glorified binge drinking and associated masculinity with alcohol consumption. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor at the University of Technology Sydney, expressed concern that Abbott, as Prime Minister, should be advocating against binge drinking instead of showcasing his masculinity through such actions. Critics argue that Abbott should set an example by demonstrating that one doesn't have to drink heavily to be considered a "true blue Aussie bloke." Despite the backlash, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating that there was nothing wrong with his actions.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County, linked to a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. The outbreak, primarily among intravenous drug users involving the painkiller Opana, has raised concerns and may pressure Pence to extend the 30-day program beyond its April 25 deadline. The program has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected about 1,400 used syringes. While Pence opposes needle exchanges, some lawmakers support them as a harm-reduction policy, and legislation to allow needle-exchange programs in high-risk counties is pending. The sustainability and funding of such programs remain uncertain.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a quiz about his favorite football club, Arsenal FC. The test, which resembled a school exam, included multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and a section requiring answers in her own words. Saskia scored 43.5 out of 50, earning an "A" grade and avoiding being dumped by her boyfriend. She shared the test on Twitter, showing mixed emotions about the experience. The boyfriend provided feedback suggesting areas for improvement, such as learning player positions and understanding that Tottenham are considered "scum" by Arsenal fans. Saskia's creative answers, like calling Eden Hazard a "p***k" and stating Alexis Sanchez is better because he is "buff" and scores lots of goals, earned her extra marks. Twitter users were divided, with some hailing the boyfriend as a "legend" and others criticizing him for taking things too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for the promise of U.S. citizenship. After retiring due to declining health, he faces deportation. Toro provided crucial information that aided in the prosecution of significant figures such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, the DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship, and he now lives in fear of being sent back to Colombia, where he believes he would be killed within hours of arrival.

A 14-year-old girl in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, India, set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. Her family reportedly advised her to remain silent about the attack. She is currently in critical condition with 70% burns at Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital. The accused men have been arrested. This incident comes amid heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following recent protests and the banning of a documentary about a notorious gang rape and murder case. The documentary detailed the gang rape and murder of 23-year-old Jyoti Singh, which led to widespread protests and international outrage.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is eager to beat rivals Manchester City in the upcoming derby at Old Trafford but will be without Robin van Persie, who is not yet fit to play despite claiming he was. Van Gaal emphasized that being fit for him is different from just being fit. The derby presents an opportunity for United to secure a second or third-place finish, avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture. Van Gaal acknowledged City's challenge and downplayed revenge as a motivator after their previous loss. Additionally, Luke Shaw is also ruled out due to insufficient fitness. Van Gaal looks forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford with home advantage.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against rising ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Barclays Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was in response to the Premier League's recent £5.14 billion TV rights deal and the high cost of tickets, which started at £64 for the sold-out game. Fans displayed banners reading "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing." The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement, Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups, who called the ticket prices "extortionate" and emphasized the need for tangible reductions to retain working-class fans. Further protests are expected after the match.

A newborn baby named Star, diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, required a life-saving liver transplant. After an unsuccessful operation to unblock her bile ducts, her parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were informed that a liver transplant was necessary for her survival. Neither parent was a suitable donor, but Jade's twin sister, Shanell Reader, volunteered to donate part of her liver. The transplant was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery, needing regular blood tests and lifelong anti-rejection medication. Shanell expressed that she did not hesitate to help her niece, emphasizing her willingness to do anything to save Star's life.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake participated in Audi's Football Challenge, competing against teammates Loic Remy and Willian. They won the first round 5-3 by firing balls into the boot of a car from close range. The players also faced challenges like sinking balls into convertible Audis from long range and playing tennis over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, leading 6-0. In the final game, Remy and Willian won by shooting from long range to sink footballs through the top of a convertible Audi. Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror of one of the Audis during the event.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, 54, from New Hampshire, caused a fatal highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger claimed he was not suicidal during his sentencing, despite prosecutors stating he told investigators he was trying to kill himself. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus's death, facing 12 to 24 years in prison. His attorneys argued he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac effects, and multiple sclerosis symptoms at the time of the crash. Dellinger's wife described him as a man of ethics, integrity, and friendship, expressing devastation for the victims' families.

Lacey Spears, from Scottsville, Kentucky, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt, resulting in his death. She was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, showing no emotion during the sentencing. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and hope for her suffering in prison on Facebook. Spears was found guilty of loading her son's feeding tube with a lethal amount of salt while he was hospitalized. The judge noted Spears' mental illness, and while prosecutors sought the maximum sentence, Spears' lawyer argued for the minimum, claiming she was a hardworking single mother. The case has sparked significant public attention and debate.

An improved influenza vaccination, now including protection against the H3N2 and B/Phuket strains, is arriving in Australia a month later than expected due to the modifications. This change was prompted by a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States, where the previous vaccine did not effectively combat these strains. High-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, can access free, government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, emphasized the importance of the updated vaccine and advised everyone to get vaccinated, as it also protects against the H1N1 strain. The new vaccine is expected to be a better match for global circulating strains and could help prevent more deaths per capita.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are addressing criticism from National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could jeopardize the management of the historic site. The critique described the tomb as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." The tomb, located in Springfield, Illinois, is a popular tourist site and the final resting place of the 16th U.S. president. The state of Illinois, facing a financial crisis, has proposed eliminating the State Historic Preservation Agency, which manages the tomb, and integrating it into another department. Despite recent renovations and repairs, the tomb has faced reduced hours and staffing due to funding cuts. Supporters of the tomb argue that the National Geographic portrayal is unfair and that the majority of visitors find the site impressive.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s and early 2000s fashion trends, highlighting styles that are making a comeback and those that should remain in the past. Notable trends include chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts. The return of JNCO's wide-leg "rave" jeans has caused dismay among those who wore them previously. The article lists nine retro fashion items that are being revisited, such as the bucket hat, camouflage print, double denim, UGG boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. Each trend is accompanied by examples of celebrities who popularized or currently wear them.

This week's trending stories included: four rainbows appearing in New York after heavy rain, a crackdown in China on hiring exotic dancers for wakes, Robert Downey Jr.'s agitation during a UK interview, the Kardashian-inspired #KylieJennerChallenge, a 102-year-old woman revisiting her past with filmmakers, a controversial prom proposal referencing bombs, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', Johnny Depp's transformation in the 'Black Mass' trailer, a 'Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'-themed pregnancy announcement, and a military dad photobombing his son's photo.

Serena Williams achieved her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, marking the occasion with a celebratory cake. This followed Andy Murray's 500th win, which was also celebrated with a cake. Williams progressed to the semi-finals by defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets (7-6, 1-6, 6-3). Although Venus Williams was defeated by Carla Suarez Navarro, Serena remained focused on the tournament, which she considers close to her hometown event. Serena will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist known for her advocacy of human rights, women's entrepreneurship, and free speech, was shot dead by two gunmen in Karachi. Mahmud, who ran a cafe called the Second Floor (T2F) that served as a hub for discussions on various progressive topics, had recently hosted a discussion on the Balochistan conflict, which is a sensitive issue in Pakistan. Despite receiving death threats, she continued to speak out and became a figurehead for non-violence and progressive values. Her death has sparked widespread grief and reflection on the dangers of free speech in Pakistan. No one has claimed responsibility for the shooting, and the motive remains unclear.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer and refugee from West Pakistan, has lived in Indian Kashmir for nearly 70 years without citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote in state elections. He and thousands of others like him are now hopeful that their refugee status, which has caused them to live in abject poverty for generations, will change following the success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party in the recent state elections. The reluctance of successive state governments to grant full rights to the West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) is due to concerns about upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. With the Bharatiya Janata Party now in power, there is hope that the plight of the WPRs will be addressed, though activists warn they are prepared to take matters into their own hands if their hopes are not met.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering an offer from Premier League leaders Chelsea, reportedly around £4 million. Chelsea plans to loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem, but Muto wants to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Muto has expressed his desire to think carefully about his future. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho has acknowledged Muto but refrained from discussing him publicly. Muto's former manager, Ranko Popovic, praised his potential and unique qualities. Chelsea's recent £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber may influence their interest in Muto.

The passage argues that England should adopt Australia's policy of selecting their best rugby players regardless of where they play in the world, to ensure they have the best chance of winning the World Cup. It criticizes England's current policy of not selecting overseas players, exemplified by England head coach Stuart Lancaster's stance. The passage highlights the improved performances of players like Matt Giteau, Steffon Armitage, and Nick Abendanon after moving to overseas clubs, and uses Jonny Wilkinson as an example of a player who thrived after moving to France. It emphasizes the importance of selecting the best possible team for the World Cup, especially as the home team, and warns against being limited by the Rugby Football Union or Premier Rugby regulations. The passage concludes by commending Australia for recognizing the value of selecting the best players available.

The Firechat app allows users to chat with friends without needing the web or a mobile signal by creating a wireless mesh network. Developers at Open Garden have created Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster to enhance these off-the-grid networks. Greenstone works with Firechat to extend the range of message transmission, currently up to 20 feet, and can store up to 1,000 recent messages with a one-year battery life. The app has been downloaded over five million times and is useful in areas with no signal, such as on planes or in underground settings, and can also save on data plans. Greenstone is still under development and is expected to be available for purchase through partnerships with manufacturers.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle from New Jersey is working to change the negative connotations associated with the word "fat" by embracing it as an honest descriptor of her body. In a TED Talk, she explained that she also refers to herself as "short" and "wife" because they are truthful descriptions of her height and marital status. Lillian believes that "fat" should not be synonymous with "ugly" and highlighted that women are often conditioned to deny being "fat" due to societal pressures. She pointed out that size discrimination in the workplace has increased by 66% over the past 30 years and that young girls often wish to be thinner. However, studies suggest that exposure to body diversity can lead to greater acceptance and preference for different body types. Lillian hopes that her burlesque performances, which showcase a "fat" body in a positive light, can help change perceptions. She began performing in 2012 and has found the experience to be empowering and body-positive. Despite some negative comments, the response to her TED Talk has been mostly positive, with many viewers sharing stories of how it helped them reevaluate their own body image.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has frequently been seen sitting on the bench with six of his teammates due to being overlooked for most of the season. Walcott participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Paris' oldest fashion house and Arsenal's official tailor since 2013, alongside teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, as well as runway model Olga Sherer. Walcott has been on the bench for 17 of Arsenal's 33 Barclays Premier League games and played the last six minutes in their recent 0-0 draw with Chelsea. He hopes to make his first start since March 14 when Arsenal faces Hull on May 30.

An auction of props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker's Cinovation Studio will take place on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection, valued at $746,100, includes over 400 items from more than 50 productions spanning Baker's 30-year career. Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from "Men in Black" ($40,000), the two-face mask from "Batman Forever" ($1,500), and the Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" ($8,000). Other items include costumes and puppets from films like "An American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," "Batman & Robin," "Hellboy," "Mighty Joe Young," and Michael Jackson's "Moonwalker." The auction offers fans a unique opportunity to own pieces of Hollywood history.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, tragically died in the French Alps after skiing with his family. He became separated from his mother and ventured into dense woodland, where he fell over a 164ft drop. His body was found by police following footprints in the snow. Carwyn was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster who was a very competent skier and snowboarder. His family expressed their devastation, stating that his death has left a vast void in their hearts. They remembered him as a caring person who brought laughter and love into their lives.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia due to societal pressures to achieve a 'size zero' figure. Obsessed with her weight, she would hide food and lie to her mother about eating, often surviving on just one piece of fruit a day. Her condition worsened, leading to a collapse and a week on a heart monitor in the hospital. After receiving support from eating disorder organizations, Laura began her recovery and has since improved her body image and self-confidence, reaching the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition promoting positive experiences for young girls.

Raheem Sterling was urged by Liverpool fans to stay at the club during the unveiling of the new home kit at Anfield. The new kit, designed by New Balance, features a gingham pattern and a new collar style. Sterling, along with teammates Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, presented the kit to fans. Despite Sterling's recent rejection of a £100,000-a-week contract offer, fans expressed their desire for him to remain with the club. The players also discussed their upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have created the largest high-definition map of dark matter, showing clumps of this mysterious substance across 0.4% of the sky. This map, created using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile, is part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES) aiming to map 12.5% of the sky over five years. The map helps astronomers study galaxy formation and the effects of dark matter, which makes up about 85% of all matter in the universe. The survey uses gravitational lensing to map dark matter's distribution and aims to understand dark energy's role in the universe's expansion. The initial map is based on 130 million telescope images and required significant computational resources.

Manchester United has intensified their efforts to sign PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch forward. United manager Louis van Gaal, who previously included Depay in the Netherlands' 2014 World Cup squad, aims to make him one of his first signings. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is also being pursued by other top European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain. PSV Eindhoven confirmed Manchester United's official approach and noted that Depay's value has increased since Tottenham's £15 million bid last summer was rejected. Depay has been praised for his talent and potential, with comparisons made to Dutch stars Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City in the Youth Cup final, taking a commanding lead from their previous match. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half, and Dominic Solanke added a late goal to secure the win. Manchester City's Isaac Buckley-Ricketts briefly leveled the score in the first half. Key players for Chelsea included Abraham, Solanke, and Fikayo Tomori, while Manchester City's Brandon Barker and Tosin Adarabioyo stood out. Chelsea's defense, led by Collins and Clarke-Salter, effectively neutralized City's attacks.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes people are born with a sexual preference and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He insists that the decision on whether to allow gay marriage should be left to state legislators, not courts. Rubio stated that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer despite disagreeing with the decision, emphasizing respect for personal choices. He announced his candidacy for president and has already received significant monetary commitments from donors.

Pablo Mandado, 27, from Spain, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, from Latvia, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue a dream of discovering different parts of the planet by bicycle. They have no specific plans, agenda, or cause, and are in no hurry. In their first year of an open-ended journey, they have covered almost 7,000 miles and traveled through 16 countries. They keep costs down by relying on free accommodation, using websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and dumpster diving for food. Their daily expenses total 2.99 euros each, with food being their only major expense at 2.74 euros per day. They started in London and have traveled through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey, with plans to continue into Asia, across the Pacific, and eventually cycle the length of the American continent.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 are suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly having a photo booth at their wedding that printed the racial slur "poor n***** party" on the bottom of some photos. The couple, who chose to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to represent them. They were not informed about the offensive photos until months after the wedding when the bride's sister disclosed the incident. James Evans, who runs Premiere Photos, has denied the allegations and reportedly told the couple to "sue" him. The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. They are seeking an apology and are not focused on monetary compensation. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if an agreement is not reached.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is taking a cautious approach in recovering from his latest concussion, which occurred during England's 47-17 victory over Italy in February. He remains uncertain about his return date after withdrawing from Harlequins' Aviva Premiership match against Saracens. Brown emphasizes the importance of recognizing concussion symptoms, influenced by World Rugby online modules, and advocates for honesty and caution to avoid long-term injuries. Similarly, Northampton wing George North has been advised not to play this season due to multiple concussions, and Ireland's Johnny Sexton was sidelined for 12 weeks earlier this term. Brown highlights the significance of being aware of concussion dangers and urges teammates to avoid playing through symptoms.

A leading expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter from Cambridge University, suggests that smartphone use and increased technological connectivity may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among couples. Research indicates that the number of times Britons are having sex each month has been decreasing since the emergence of the internet. According to Spiegelhalter's book "Sex by Numbers," a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the erosion of boundaries between home, work, and the outside world, leading to busier lives and less time spent with partners. Additionally, the constant connectivity through emails and other digital communications has been cited as a reason why sex falls down the list of priorities.

The passage discusses the dramatic decline in the popularity and value of Tibetan Mastiffs in China. Once considered status symbols and sold for up to £1.2 million, these dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat used in cheap hotpots. This decline is partly due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has made people hesitant to give or accept the dogs as gifts. Additionally, bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities have impacted the breed's popularity. The passage also mentions that unscrupulous breeders and gangs contribute to the problem by selling or stealing the dogs for slaughter. The breed's boom began in 2005, but urbanization and cross-breeding have led to a glut of poor-quality dogs.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every woman claimed to have experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half reporting their first incident before the age of 18. The harassment ranged from verbal abuse and unwanted attention to sexual assault and rape. This pervasive issue has led to widespread fear among women, with six out of ten afraid of being attacked on public transport, compared to three out of ten men. The survey prompted calls for a campaign to address and reduce sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains. The report emphasized the need for women to be educated about their rights and for aggressors to understand that their actions are criminal and punishable by law.

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, organized a competition called #everydayfix to address common daily emergencies. They surveyed 2,000 people to identify the top ten everyday emergencies causing undue stress, such as not being able to sleep (46%), losing keys (37%), and running out of phone battery (31%). Design groups, including Makerversity, created prototype products to tackle these issues. Three shortlisted products are:

1. **Snooze**: An alarm clock by Instruments that connects with a phone to silence notifications for better sleep.
2. **Forget Me Lock**: A device by Onn Studio that attaches to a key, showing green when the door is open and red when locked.
3. **Nipper**: The world's smallest mobile phone charger by Impulse, using household batteries to charge phones.

The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter with the hashtag #everydayfix. The product with the most retweets by April 46 will enter a Kickstarter campaign for development. Other notable non-shortlisted products included a helmet with bone conduction headphones for cycling directions and a parking pin to alert users when a parking space becomes available.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for awarding £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs. Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim, also sits on the charity's board. Critics, including Keith Vaz, argue this is inappropriate and a conflict of interest. The investigation will determine if any conflict of interest rules were violated. Baird maintains that all procedures were followed, while Sim is set to retire in June.

Three people have been sent to prison and two more are awaiting sentencing for their involvement in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, led the gang known as the 'tattoo terrorists' and was sentenced to 20 years in prison. Campbell believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and also thought Valecce had stolen money and marijuana. Sandra Ng, 19, Campbell's girlfriend, received 23 months in prison, while Carl Halin, 18, received the same sentence as Campbell. David Thomas, 28, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively. Valecce suffered severe injuries and has since had the tattoos removed but continues to experience psychological trauma.

Manchester United has intensified their efforts to sign PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, making an official approach for the 21-year-old Dutch forward. United manager Louis van Gaal, who previously included Depay in the Netherlands' 2014 World Cup squad, is eager to make him one of his first signings. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, has attracted interest from several top European clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain. PSV Eindhoven's technical director Marcel Brands confirmed the contact from Manchester United and PSG, noting that the offers involve larger sums than a previous £15 million bid from Tottenham last summer. Depay, who started his career at VV Moordrecht and later joined PSV at age 12, has been compared to Dutch stars Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo for his talent and potential.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized as status symbols in China and sold for up to £1.2 million, have seen a dramatic decline in popularity. This decline is partly due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has made gifting these dogs to officials taboo. Additionally, bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities have impacted the breed's popularity. As a result, many Tibetan mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses, where their meat is used in cheap hotpots, and their skin for leather products. Animal welfare workers have rescued some of these dogs, finding them in poor conditions. The breed's decline is also attributed to cross-breeding and the realization that these dogs are not suited to urban living.
